website         = [https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/infectiousdiseases/2019-coronavirus.html Alabama Department of Public Health]

column1: The [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]] was confirmed to have reached the U.S. state of [[Alabama]] in March 2020. As of April 13, 2020, the Alabama Department of Public Health reported 3,692 cases of COVID-19 and 99 deaths.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)
column7: title=Alabama coronavirus cases climb to 39; Closures ordered in some counties

column1: {{2019–20 coronavirus pandemic data/United States/Alabama medical cases chart}}

column2: title         = New Cases Reported Per Day in Alabama

column1: cases in Alabama, United States,\" shown

column2: title         = Deaths Per Day Reported in Alabama

column1: cases in Alabama, United States,\" shown

On January 22, the [[Alabama Department of Public Health]] (ADPH) asked healthcare providers to conduct screening of patients seeking care for influenza-like illnesses with travel to Wuhan, China, and said the \"CDC continues to believe the risk of 2019-nCoV to the American public at large remains low at this time.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=ADPH joins with CDC and other state health departments to prevent the spread of new coronavirus {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)

column1: On February 4, the Alabama Department of Public Health asked travelers to mainland China who returned to the United States on or after January 22, 2020 to Infectious Diseases and Outbreaks Division as soon as they arrive in Alabama.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=ADPH initiates monitoring activities for travelers from mainland China for 2019-nCoV {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)
column5: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> On the same day, [[Kay Ivey
column6: Alabama Governor Kay Ivey]] delivered the \"State of the State\" address, with no mention of COVID-19.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Governor Ivey Delivers 2020 State of the State Address
column20: title=2020 State of the State Address}}</ref>

column1: On February 21, the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services
column2: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS) announced that an Anniston, Alabama facility would be used as a COVID-19 quarantine center.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Anniston city leaders blindsided by plan to use local FEMA facility as part of Coronavirus quarantine
column9: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref> On February 23, Governor Ivey announced cancellation of the HHS plans to use an Anniston, Alabama facility as a quarantine center.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Governor Kay Ivey: President Trump cancels plans for cruise ship coronavirus quarantine in Alabama

column1: On February 28, the Alabama Department of Public Health recommended individuals protect themselves from COVID-19 by getting a flu shot and \"other normal precautions\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=ADPH recommends flu shot and other normal precautions amid COVID-19 outbreak {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)

column1: On March 2, the Alabama Department of Public Health advised individuals to \"wash your hands frequently, avoid touching your face, cover coughs and sneezes, stay home when you are ill, and practice social distancing strategies\". ADPH also asks universities and colleges to implement plans to mitigate spread of disease on their campuses.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Alabama is prepared for COVID-19; supports CDC recommendations for returning travelers {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)
column5: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> On March 5, the Alabama Department of Public Health announced state laboratory capability of COVID-19 testing and criteria for testing eligibility.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=ADPH state laboratory now tests for novel coronavirus COVID-19 {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)
column9: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> March 6 saw the formation of Alabama Coronavirus task force.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: On March 12, all schools were closed from March 18 until April 6.<ref>[https://www.al.com/news/f80301-coronavirus-covid19-in-alabama-what-you-need-to-know-now.html Live updates: K-12 schools to close; 6 coronavirus cases in Alabama] AL.com</ref> Governor Ivey said: \"There's no need to panic or close huge events right now.\" Urges Alabamans to wash hands, cover coughs, and [[fist bump]] instead of [[handshake
column4: title='There's no need to panic:' Gov. Kay Ivey urges coronavirus calm for Alabamians
column7: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> On March 13, Governor Ivey declared a state of emergency due to the spread of the coronavirus.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=State of emergency declared in Alabama, 1 coronavirus case confirmed in Jefferson County
column13: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> On March 15, Gov. Ivey authorized state agency directors to implement work from home and flexible work schedules.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=Effective on Monday, March 16, I will be authorizing agency directors to implement telework, flexible work schedules and practice social distancing for the next three weeks. #alpolitics #COVID19
column21: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> On March 16, the Alabama Department of Public Health announced recommendations concerning public gatherings, food establishment and other retail venues, and businesses, including no mass gatherings of 50+ persons or more.<ref>{{Cite web
column23: title=ADPH offers new recommendations regarding public gatherings in response to COVID-19 {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)

column1: On March 18, statewide health order prohibited all non-work related gatherings of 25+ persons or any non-work related gatherings that cannot maintain consistent six-foot spacing between people.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Governor Ivey, ADPH issue statewide health order
column8: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> The Alabama Department of Public Health confirmed that the number of positive coronavirus cases had increased to 78 in the state.<ref name=\":1\" /> Public and private beaches closed.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Ivey closes all Alabama beaches both public and private because of coronavirus
column14: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> Governor Ivey announced that Alabama's Primary Runoff Election would be postponed to July 14.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: title=Governor Ivey Announces New Primary Runoff Election Date
column18: website=Office of the Governor of Alabama

column1: On March 20, the total number of confirmed cases has surpassed 100, to 106.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Alabama now up to 106 confirmed COVID-19 cases
column6: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> Gov. Ivey authorizes up to 100 Alabama National Guard members to assist with response \"if it becomes necessary.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Governor Ivey authorizes National Guard to help with COVID-19 operations if necessary
column13: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> The Alabama Department of Public Health refined guidance on public gatherings.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=State Health Officer issues amended health order suspending public gatherings {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)
column17: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> [[Auburn University]] announced postponement of its spring graduation ceremony and a move to fully online classes after spring break.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=Auburn University postpones spring graduation ceremony, resuming online-only classes after break

column1: On March 22, the total number of confirmed cases reached 150.{{citation needed
column3: Birmingham]] issued a stay-at-home order (as a 24-hour curfew) effective March 24 to April 3.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=City of Birmingham under Shelter in Place in order
column8: url=https://www.wsfa.com/2020/03/24/birminghams-mayor-proposes-ordinance-shelter-place-during-coronavirus-outbreak/}}</ref> On March 25, the total number of confirmed cases jumped to 386 from 219. The number of people tested is 2,812.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=COVID-19 {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)
column12: access-date=2020-03-25}}</ref> The first death in the state is reported in Jackson County.<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Alabama reports first coronavirus death as cases near 400-date=2020-03-26}}</ref> [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama
column15: Tuscaloosa]] city mayor [[Walt Maddox]] issued a city-wide curfew, lasting from 10:00 p.m. until 5:00 a.m. each day, effective March 27 to April 3.<ref>{{cite news
column16: title=Tuscaloosa Mayor Walt Maddox issues curfew for city

column1: At a March 26 press conference, Governor Ivey said that she would not issue a shelter-in-place order, saying \"... we are not Louisiana, we are not New York state, we are not California ... right now is not the time to order people to shelter in place.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus: Ivey says 'right now is not the time' for Alabama-wide shelter-in-place order
column6: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref> Tuscaloosa extended its city-wide curfew to 24 hours, beginning March 29 at 10:00 p.m., set to last an additional week. The Tuscaloosa stay-at-home order (the second in the state) came after [[Attorney General of Alabama
column8: Steve Marshall]]'s opinion published on the same day that provided cities and counties with more authority to combat the pandemic.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Maddox extends Tuscaloosa's curfew to 24 hours, citing 'rapidly developing situation'

column1: On March 27, all \"non-essential businesses\" in the state were ordered to be closed until April 17, including barbershops, furniture stores, gyms, casinos, theaters, arcades, night clubs, salons and spas. [[Alcoholic beverage control state
column2: ABC stores]] would remain open. Governor Ivey again refused to issue a state-wide shelter-in-place order, saying \"I have the responsibility to look statewide and in this case, one size does not fit all\" and that she has to \"keep an eye on the economy\"; she added that she would not object to county and city-level containment efforts.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=All 'non-essential businesses' closed statewide until April 17; Ivey doesn't issue shelter-in-place
column8: Steven Reed]] enacted an indefinite, 10:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. curfew starting the night of March 27 to help contain COVID-19. The order does not impact essential businesses.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Montgomery mayor enacts indefinite, seven-hour curfew starting 10 p.m. tonight

column1: The Alabama Department of Labor reported that from March 22–26, 59,783 Alabamians filed for [[Unemployment benefits
column2: unemployment]], a five-fold growth over last week's 9,138 filings.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Alabama unemployment claims surge to 60,000 this week as coronavirus creates economic havoc

column1: Archbishop [[Thomas John Rodi]] of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mobile
column2: Archdiocese of Mobile]] and Bishop [[Robert Joseph Baker]] of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Birmingham in Alabama
column3: Diocese of Birmingham]] continued the suspension of public [[Mass in the Catholic Church
column4: Mass]] in Alabama through April 18, meaning no Easter Sunday Mass on April 12, in what Rodi called a \"painful decision\". Baker and Rodi initially issued the suspension of public Mass on March 17.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Bishops call off public Mass for Easter in Alabama

column1: By the end of March 28, there were 720 confirmed COVID-19 cases in Alabama.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Alabama coronavirus spread on similar pace with Tennessee, Louisiana based on last three days
column6: work=WAAYTV}}</ref> Although the confirmed state death count was three at the time, [[Lee County, Alabama
column7: Lee County]] Coroner Bill Harris said that of the around 19 COVID-19 patients at the [[List of hospitals in Alabama
column8: East Alabama Medical Center]] in [[Opelika, Alabama
column9: Opelika]], five had died between the morning of March 27 and 3:15 p.m. on March 28. Two of the deaths were Lee County residents and three were residents from [[Chambers County, Alabama
column14: title=Coronavirus kills 5 people in Lee County in 1 day, coroner says
column15: work=AL.com}}</ref> Meanwhile, by March 28, the virus was confirmed in at least six [[Nursing home care
column16: nursing homes]] in the state.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=Coronavirus confirmed in six Alabama nursing homes

column2: Apple]] donated 63,000 [[N95 mask]]s for Alabama healthcare providers.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Coronavirus supplies: Apple donates 63,000 N-95 masks to Alabama

column1: By 5:30 p.m. on March 29, Alabama had 827 confirmed cases while the death toll reached at least 10 after the East Alabama Medical Center announced its sixth fatality in three days, although the official count provided by ADPH was only 4 deaths. By this time the EAMC was the only hospital in the state to announce a COVID-19 death. The [[Mobile County, Alabama
column2: Mobile County]] Health Department also recorded a death not yet reflected by ADPH numbers.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Death toll from coronavirus rises in Auburn area, Alabama now has at least 10 deaths
column7: accessdate=March 30, 2020}}</ref> Residents in the Opelika area were holding a \"Park and [[Prayer
column8: Pray]]\" service twice daily in support of the hospital staff at the EAMC.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=Community holds 'Park and Pray' twice daily at East Alabama Medical Center — 'God is in this'}}</ref> A similar scene was observed in the [[DCH Regional Medical Center]] parking lot in Tuscaloosa where a local church organized a worship service there.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=Church gathers to worship outside DCH Regional Medical Center in Tuscaloosa

column1: On April 1, COVID-19 cases in Alabama reached 1,000 cases, according to the ADPH. 24 total deaths were reported with 17 confirmed.<ref>{{cite news
On April 2, by 9:00 pm, confirmed statewide cases rose to 1,270 out of 8,619 people thus far tested, with 17 confirmed deaths and 32 reported deaths statewide.<ref>{{cite news
Alabama was projected to have the fourth-highest rate of COVID-19 fatalities in the nation.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Alabama projected to have fourth highest rate of COVID-19 fatalities in nation
column6: accessdate=April 3, 2020}}</ref> Despite this projection, Governor Kay Ivey continued to resist demands to issue a state-wide shelter-in-place order but issued her fifth Supplemental State of Emergency (the third was on March 23 and the fourth was on March 27) to reduce [[red tape]] for healthcare providers, including allowing certified registered nurse practitioners, nurse midwives, physician assistants and anesthesia assistants to practice in a licensed health care facility. She also ordered the state board to adopt emergency rules to allow expedited reinstatement of medical licenses; moved to expand capacity of health care facilities; and moved to allow local jails release [[probation]] or [[parole]] violators who have been in custody for more than 20 days without a hearing.<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Gov. Ivey issues Supplemental State of Emergency to cut red tape for healthcare providers

column1: It was reported that everyday since March 23, the ADPH was sharing a list of addresses of confirmed COVID-19 patients with the Alabama 911 Board to disseminate to local 911 response districts, reportedly to protect [[first responders]] from becoming infected–a possible breach of [[Privacy law
column2: patient confidentiality law]]. [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Massachusetts
column3: Massachusetts]] was the only other state known to be doing this at the time. The 911 Board said the policy was implemented after numerous state agencies expressed concerns about protecting first responders.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Alabama sharing addresses of coronavirus patients with 911 responders

column1: On April 3, Governor Ivey issued a statewide stay-at-home order effective April 4 until April 30.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Stay-at-home order issued for Alabama: What you can and can't do
column9: Mobile]] issued a stay-at-home order effective April 4 until April 30.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Mayor Stimpson announces stay-at-home order for Mobile

column2: Montgomery County]] authorities said they received 5,880 [[surgical mask]]s from the [[Strategic National Stockpile]] with a 2010 expiration date had [[dry rot]] and were useless.<ref>[https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/491015-alabama-county-received-5000-rotted-masks-from-national-stockpile Alabama county received 5,000 rotted masks from national stockpile] BY KAELAN DEESE, The Hill, 3 Apr 2020</ref>

column1: On March 12, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] cancelled all winter and spring tournaments, most notably the [[NCAA Division I
column2: Division I]] [[2020 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
column3: men]]'s and [[2020 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament
column4: women]]'s basketball tournaments, affecting colleges and universities statewide.<ref name=ncaa>[https://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/media-center/news/ncaa-cancels-remaining-winter-and-spring-championships NCAA cancels remaining winter and spring championships] NCAA, March 12, 2020</ref> On March 16, the [[National Junior College Athletic Association]] also canceled the remainder of the winter seasons as well as the spring seasons.<ref>[https://www.mlive.com/sports/2020/03/njcaa-cancels-spring-sports-basketball-nationals-amid-coronavirus-outbreak.html NJCAA cancels spring sports, basketball nationals amid coronavirus outbreak] MLive.com, March 16, 2020</ref>

column1: The [[2021 World Games]] in Birmingham, originally scheduled for July 15–25, 2021, was postponed to July 7–17, 2022.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=World Games in Birmingham rescheduled to July 2022

column1: [[Alabama Crimson Tide football]] head coach [[Nick Saban]] and his Nick's Kids Foundation donated to food banks, contributed to the [[2-1-1
column2: 211]] program, provided meals to [[DCH Regional Medical Center]] workers, and filmed [[Public service announcement
column5: title=How Nick Saban views his role helping during coronavirus crisis

column2: Mobicon]],  an annual fan convention held in [[Mobile, Alabama
column3: Mobile]] announced that the 2020 iteration of the convention scheduled for the last weekend of May had been postponed in response to the coronavirus pandemic.{{citation needed

column4: title=City of Birmingham under Shelter in Place in order
column8: url=https://www.wsfa.com/2020/03/24/birminghams-mayor-proposes-ordinance-shelter-place-during-coronavirus-outbreak/}}</ref> On March 25, the total number of confirmed cases jumped to 386 from 219. The number of people tested is 2,812.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=COVID-19 {{!}} Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH)
column12: access-date=2020-03-25}}</ref> The first death in the state is reported in Jackson County.<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Alabama reports first coronavirus death as cases near 400-date=2020-03-26}}</ref> [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama
column15: Tuscaloosa]] city mayor [[Walt Maddox]] issued a city-wide curfew, lasting from 10:00 p.m. until 5:00 a.m. each day, effective March 27 to April 3.<ref>{{cite news
column16: title=Tuscaloosa Mayor Walt Maddox issues curfew for city

column1: At a March 26 press conference, Governor Ivey said that she would not issue a shelter-in-place order, saying \"... we are not Louisiana, we are not New York state, we are not California ... right now is not the time to order people to shelter in place.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus: Ivey says 'right now is not the time' for Alabama-wide shelter-in-place order
column6: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref> Tuscaloosa extended its city-wide curfew to 24 hours, beginning March 29 at 10:00 p.m., set to last an additional week. The Tuscaloosa stay-at-home order (the second in the state) came after [[Attorney General of Alabama
column8: Steve Marshall]]'s opinion published on the same day that provided cities and counties with more authority to combat the pandemic.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Maddox extends Tuscaloosa's curfew to 24 hours, citing 'rapidly developing situation'

column1: On March 27, all \"non-essential businesses\" in the state were ordered to be closed until April 17, including barbershops, furniture stores, gyms, casinos, theaters, arcades, night clubs, salons and spas. [[Alcoholic beverage control state
column2: ABC stores]] would remain open. Governor Ivey again refused to issue a state-wide shelter-in-place order, saying \"I have the responsibility to look statewide and in this case, one size does not fit all\" and that she has to \"keep an eye on the economy\"; she added that she would not object to county and city-level containment efforts.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=All 'non-essential businesses' closed statewide until April 17; Ivey doesn't issue shelter-in-place
column8: Steven Reed]] enacted an indefinite, 10:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. curfew starting the night of March 27 to help contain COVID-19. The order does not impact essential businesses.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Montgomery mayor enacts indefinite, seven-hour curfew starting 10 p.m. tonight

column1: The Alabama Department of Labor reported that from March 22–26, 59,783 Alabamians filed for [[Unemployment benefits
column2: unemployment]], a five-fold growth over last week's 9,138 filings.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Alabama unemployment claims surge to 60,000 this week as coronavirus creates economic havoc

column1: Archbishop [[Thomas John Rodi]] of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mobile
column2: Archdiocese of Mobile]] and Bishop [[Robert Joseph Baker]] of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Birmingham in Alabama
column3: Diocese of Birmingham]] continued the suspension of public [[Mass in the Catholic Church
column4: Mass]] in Alabama through April 18, meaning no Easter Sunday Mass on April 12, in what Rodi called a \"painful decision\". Baker and Rodi initially issued the suspension of public Mass on March 17.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Bishops call off public Mass for Easter in Alabama

column1: By the end of March 28, there were 720 confirmed COVID-19 cases in Alabama.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Alabama coronavirus spread on similar pace with Tennessee, Louisiana based on last three days
column6: work=WAAYTV}}</ref> Although the confirmed state death count was three at the time, [[Lee County, Alabama
column7: Lee County]] Coroner Bill Harris said that of the around 19 COVID-19 patients at the [[List of hospitals in Alabama
column8: East Alabama Medical Center]] in [[Opelika, Alabama
column9: Opelika]], five had died between the morning of March 27 and 3:15 p.m. on March 28. Two of the deaths were Lee County residents and three were residents from [[Chambers County, Alabama
column14: title=Coronavirus kills 5 people in Lee County in 1 day, coroner says
column15: work=AL.com}}</ref> Meanwhile, by March 28, the virus was confirmed in at least six [[Nursing home care
column16: nursing homes]] in the state.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=Coronavirus confirmed in six Alabama nursing homes

column2: Apple]] donated 63,000 [[N95 mask]]s for Alabama healthcare providers.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Coronavirus supplies: Apple donates 63,000 N-95 masks to Alabama

column1: By 5:30 p.m. on March 29, Alabama had 827 confirmed cases while the death toll reached at least 10 after the East Alabama Medical Center announced its sixth fatality in three days, although the official count provided by ADPH was only 4 deaths. By this time the EAMC was the only hospital in the state to announce a COVID-19 death. The [[Mobile County, Alabama
column2: Mobile County]] Health Department also recorded a death not yet reflected by ADPH numbers.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Death toll from coronavirus rises in Auburn area, Alabama now has at least 10 deaths
column7: accessdate=March 30, 2020}}</ref> Residents in the Opelika area were holding a \"Park and [[Prayer
column8: Pray]]\" service twice daily in support of the hospital staff at the EAMC.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=Community holds 'Park and Pray' twice daily at East Alabama Medical Center — 'God is in this'}}</ref> A similar scene was observed in the [[DCH Regional Medical Center]] parking lot in Tuscaloosa where a local church organized a worship service there.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=Church gathers to worship outside DCH Regional Medical Center in Tuscaloosa

column1: On April 1, COVID-19 cases in Alabama reached 1,000 cases, according to the ADPH. 24 total deaths were reported with 17 confirmed.<ref>{{cite news
On April 2, by 9:00 pm, confirmed statewide cases rose to 1,270 out of 8,619 people thus far tested, with 17 confirmed deaths and 32 reported deaths statewide.<ref>{{cite news
Alabama was projected to have the fourth-highest rate of COVID-19 fatalities in the nation.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Alabama projected to have fourth highest rate of COVID-19 fatalities in nation
column6: accessdate=April 3, 2020}}</ref> Despite this projection, Governor Kay Ivey continued to resist demands to issue a state-wide shelter-in-place order but issued her fifth Supplemental State of Emergency (the third was on March 23 and the fourth was on March 27) to reduce [[red tape]] for healthcare providers, including allowing certified registered nurse practitioners, nurse midwives, physician assistants and anesthesia assistants to practice in a licensed health care facility. She also ordered the state board to adopt emergency rules to allow expedited reinstatement of medical licenses; moved to expand capacity of health care facilities; and moved to allow local jails release [[probation]] or [[parole]] violators who have been in custody for more than 20 days without a hearing.<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Gov. Ivey issues Supplemental State of Emergency to cut red tape for healthcare providers

column1: It was reported that everyday since March 23, the ADPH was sharing a list of addresses of confirmed COVID-19 patients with the Alabama 911 Board to disseminate to local 911 response districts, reportedly to protect [[first responders]] from becoming infected–a possible breach of [[Privacy law
column2: patient confidentiality law]]. [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Massachusetts
column3: Massachusetts]] was the only other state known to be doing this at the time. The 911 Board said the policy was implemented after numerous state agencies expressed concerns about protecting first responders.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Alabama sharing addresses of coronavirus patients with 911 responders

column1: On April 3, Governor Ivey issued a statewide stay-at-home order effective April 4 until April 30.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Stay-at-home order issued for Alabama: What you can and can't do
column9: Mobile]] issued a stay-at-home order effective April 4 until April 30.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Mayor Stimpson announces stay-at-home order for Mobile

column2: Montgomery County]] authorities said they received 5,880 [[surgical mask]]s from the [[Strategic National Stockpile]] with a 2010 expiration date had [[dry rot]] and were useless.<ref>[https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/491015-alabama-county-received-5000-rotted-masks-from-national-stockpile Alabama county received 5,000 rotted masks from national stockpile] BY KAELAN DEESE, The Hill, 3 Apr 2020</ref>

column1: On March 12, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] cancelled all winter and spring tournaments, most notably the [[NCAA Division I
column2: Division I]] [[2020 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
column3: men]]'s and [[2020 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament
column4: women]]'s basketball tournaments, affecting colleges and universities statewide.<ref name=ncaa>[https://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/media-center/news/ncaa-cancels-remaining-winter-and-spring-championships NCAA cancels remaining winter and spring championships] NCAA, March 12, 2020</ref> On March 16, the [[National Junior College Athletic Association]] also canceled the remainder of the winter seasons as well as the spring seasons.<ref>[https://www.mlive.com/sports/2020/03/njcaa-cancels-spring-sports-basketball-nationals-amid-coronavirus-outbreak.html NJCAA cancels spring sports, basketball nationals amid coronavirus outbreak] MLive.com, March 16, 2020</ref>

column1: The [[2021 World Games]] in Birmingham, originally scheduled for July 15–25, 2021, was postponed to July 7–17, 2022.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=World Games in Birmingham rescheduled to July 2022

column5: title=How Nick Saban views his role helping during coronavirus crisis

column1: According to the [[Federation of American Scientists]], an organization that assesses nuclear weapon stockpiles, as of 2018, the [[Russia
column2: Russian Federation]] possesses approximately 6,500 nuclear warheads.<ref name=FAS/>.\"<ref name=\"autogenerated1\">{{cite web
column4: title=Federation of American Scientists :: Status of World Nuclear Forces<!-- Bot generated title -->
column5: publisher=}}</ref> In addition to nuclear weapons, Russia declared an arsenal of 39,967 tons of [[chemical weapon]]s in 1997.<ref name=\"NTIchem\" /><ref name=\"CSP16\">{{cite web
column7: title=Opening Statement by the Director-General to the Conference of the States Parties at its Sixteenth Session
column10: publisher=[[OPCW]]}}</ref> The [[Soviet Union]] ratified the [[Geneva Protocol]] on April 5, 1928 with reservations. The reservations were dropped on January 18, 2001. Russia is also party to the [[Biological Weapons Convention]] and the [[Chemical Weapons Convention]]. The Soviet Union had a peak stockpile of 45,000 nuclear warheads in 1986.<ref name=\"NorrisKristensenGlobal\">Robert S. Norris and Hans M. Kristensen, \"[http://thebulletin.metapress.com/content/c4120650912x74k7/fulltext.pdf Global nuclear stockpiles, 1945-2006],\" Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists 62, no. 4 (July/August 2006), 64-66.</ref> It is estimated that from 1949 to 1991 the Soviet Union produced approximately 55,000 nuclear warheads.<ref>{{cite web
column15: date=December 1993}}</ref> In early 2019, more than 90% of the world's 13,865 [[List of states with nuclear weapons
column16: nuclear weapons]] were owned by Russia and the United States.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Global Nuclear Arsenal Declines, But Future Cuts Uncertain Amid U.S.-Russia Tensions

column1: At the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union
column2: dissolution]] of the [[Soviet Union]] in 1991, Soviet nuclear weapons were deployed in four of the new republics: Russia, [[Ukraine]], [[Belarus]] and [[Kazakhstan]]. In May 1992, these four states signed the [[Lisbon Protocol]], agreeing to join the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]], with Russia the [[successor state]] to the Soviet Union as a nuclear state, and the other three states joining as non-nuclear states.

column1: Ukraine agreed to give up its weapons to Russia, in exchange for guarantees of Ukrainian territory from Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States, known as the [[Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances]]. China and France also made statements in support of the memorandum.<ref>{{cite web

The exact number of nuclear warheads is a state secret and is therefore a matter of guesswork. The [[Federation of American Scientists]] estimates that Russia possesses 6,500 nuclear weapons, while the United States has 6,185; Russia and the U.S. each have 1,600 active deployed strategic nuclear warheads.<ref name=FAS/><ref>{{cite journal
column3: journal = Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists

column1: During an annual state-of-the-nation address given on March 1, 2018, President [[Vladimir Putin]] publicly claimed that Russia was now in possession of several new classes of nuclear weapons, including some with capabilities previously speculated to exist. Putin discussed several new or upgraded weapons, including a [[Boost-glide
column2: hypersonic glide vehicle]] known as the [[Avangard (hypersonic glide vehicle)
column3: Avangard]] capable of performing sharp maneuvers while traveling at 20 times the speed of sound making it \"absolutely invulnerable for any missile defense system.\" <ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/putin-boasts-russian-nuclear-weapons-53433951]{{dead link
column4: date=June 2019}}</ref> Putin also discussed the existence of a nuclear powered underwater torpedo and a nuclear powered [[cruise missile]] ([[9M730 Burevestnik]]), both with effectively unlimited range. He also discussed that Russia had tested a new class of traditional ICBM called the Sarmat, which expanded upon the range and carrying capability of the Soviet-era Satan ICBM. Animations of these weapons were shown in front of the live and televised audience, and Putin suggested that an online poll be conducted to give them official public names.<ref>{{cite web

column1: According to a Russian military doctrine stated in 2010, nuclear weapons could be used by Russia \"in response to the use of nuclear and other types of weapons of mass destruction against it or its allies, and also in case of aggression against Russia with the use of conventional weapons when the very existence of the state is threatened\".<ref name=\"rus_mil_doc\">[http://www.kremlin.ru/ref_notes/461 Russian military doctrine] (in Russian)</ref> Most military analysts believe that, in this case, Russia would pursue an 'escalate to de-escalate’ strategy, initiating limited nuclear exchange to bring adversaries to the negotiating table. Russia will also threaten nuclear conflict to discourage initial escalation of any major conventional conflict.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Getting Russia's nuclear strategy mostly right
Large stockpile with global range (dark blue)]]

column1: After the [[Korean War]], the [[Soviet Union]] transferred nuclear technology and weapons to the [[People's Republic of China]] as an adversary of the United States and [[NATO]]. According to [[Ion Mihai Pacepa]], \"Khrushchev's nuclear-proliferation process started with Communist China in April 1955, when the new ruler in the Kremlin consented to supply Beijing a sample atomic bomb and to help with its mass production. Subsequently, the Soviet Union built all the essentials of China's new military nuclear industry.\"<ref name=\"bomb\">[http://article.nationalreview.com/?q=YmU3NjM4ZTg3NjViMTUyNWJmYWYzMDE4ZmRhOTQxZmI= Tyrants and the Bomb] {{webarchive
column3: date=June 6, 2009 }} - by [[Ion Mihai Pacepa]], ''[[National Review]]'', October 17, 2006</ref>

column1: Russia is one of the five \"Nuclear Weapons States\" (NWS) under the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]] (NPT), which Russia ratified (as the [[Soviet Union]]) in 1968.

Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, a number of Soviet-era nuclear warheads remained on the territories of Belarus, Ukraine, and Kazakhstan. Under the terms of the [[Lisbon Protocol]] to the NPT, and following the 1995 Trilateral Agreement between Russia, Belarus, and the USA, these were transferred to Russia, leaving Russia as the sole inheritor of the Soviet nuclear arsenal. It is estimated that the Soviet Union had approximately 45,000 nuclear weapons stockpiled at the time of its collapse.

The collapse of the Soviet Union allowed for a warming of relations with NATO. Fears of a [[nuclear holocaust]] lessened. In September 1997, the former secretary of the Russian Security Council Alexander Lebed claimed 100 \"suitcase sized\" nuclear weapons were unaccounted for. He said he was attempting to inventory the weapons when he was fired by President Boris Yeltsin in October 1996.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Russian Officials Deny Claims Of Missing Nuclear Weapons
column5: accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> Indeed, several US politicians have expressed worries and promised legislation addressing the threat.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Nuclear Dangers: Fear Increases of Terrorists Getting Hands on 'Loose' Warheads as Security Slips

column4: [[Dmitry Medvedev]] with [[Barack Obama]] after signing the [[New START]] treaty in Prague, 2010]]

column1: In 2002, the United States and Russia agreed to reduce their stockpiles to not more than 2,700 warheads each in the [[SORT]] treaty. In 2003, the US rejected Russian proposals to further reduce each nation's nuclear stockpiles to 1,500. Russia, in turn, refused to discuss reduction of [[tactical nuclear weapons]].<ref name=\"trenin\">[http://ifri.org/files/Securite_defense/prolif_paper_Trenin.pdf Russia's Nuclear Policy in the 21st Century Environment] {{webarchive
column3: date=February 27, 2008 }} - analysis by Dmitri Trenin, IFRI Proliferation Papers n°13, 2005</ref>

column1: After U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] withdrew from the 1972 [[Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty]], Russia responded by building-up their [[Russia and weapons of mass destruction#Nuclear weapons
column2: nuclear capabilities]], in such a way as to counterbalance U.S. capabilities.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Russia's Nuclear Weapons Buildup Is Aimed at Beating U.S. Missile Defenses

column1: Russia decided not to sign the UN treaty on the [[Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons
column2: Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons]], which was adopted on 7 July 2017 by 122 States.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=122 countries adopt 'historic' UN treaty to ban nuclear weapons

column1: Most analysts agree that Russia’s nuclear strategy under Putin eventually brought it into violation of the 1987 [[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty]] (although this is not confirmed).<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Russia may have violated the INF Treaty. Here's how the United States appears to have done the same.
column6: language=en-US}}</ref> According to Russian officials, the American decision to deploy [[United States national missile defense
column7: the missile defense system]] in Europe was a violation of the treaty.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Russia Calls New U.S. Missile Defense System a 'Direct Threat'
column13: publisher=NYT}}</ref> U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] announced on 20 October 2018 that the U.S. would no longer consider itself bound by the treaty’s provisions, raising nuclear tensions between the two powers.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Russia Violated an Arms Treaty. Trump Ditched It, Making the Nuclear Threat Even Worse.

column1: There were allegations that Russia contributed to [[North Korean nuclear program]], selling it the equipment for the safe storage and transportation of nuclear materials.<ref name=\"Korea\">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/1523468/Russia-secretly-offered-North-Korea-nuclear-technology.html Russia secretly offered North Korea nuclear technology] - by a Special Correspondent in Pyongyang and Michael Hirst, ''Telegraph'', September 7, 2006.</ref> Nevertheless, Russia condemned North Korean nuclear tests since then.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Russia expresses serious concern over DPRK nuke issue

column1: According to high-ranking Russian [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)
column3: Sergei Tretyakov]], a businessman told him that he keeps his own nuclear bomb at his [[dacha]] outside [[Moscow]].<ref name=\"Comrade J\">Pete Earley, \"Comrade J: The Untold Secrets of Russia's Master Spy in America After the End of the Cold War\", Penguin Books, 2007, {{ISBN

column1: Russia is allegedly making efforts to build its influential hold in Africa for earning several billions pounds by selling nuclear technology to developing African countries.<ref>{{cite_web
column3: title=Guardian: Russia pushing 'unsuitable' nuclear power in Africa

column2: GRU]] defector [[Stanislav Lunev]] described alleged Soviet plans for using [[tactical nuclear weapons]] for [[sabotage]] against the United States in the event of war. He described Soviet-made [[suitcase nukes]] identified as RA-115s (or RA-115-01s for submersible weapons) which weigh from fifty to sixty pounds (23 kg - 27 kg). These portable bombs can last for many years if wired to an electric source. \"In case there is a loss of power, there is a battery backup. If the battery runs low, the weapon has a transmitter that sends a coded message – either by satellite or directly to a GRU post at a Russian embassy or consulate.\".<ref name=\"Lunev\">[[Stanislav Lunev]]. ''Through the Eyes of the Enemy: The Autobiography of Stanislav Lunev'', Regnery Publishing, Inc., 1998. {{ISBN

column1: Lunev was personally looking for hiding places for weapons caches in the [[Shenandoah Valley]] area.<ref name=\"Lunev\"/> He said that \"it is surprisingly easy to smuggle nuclear weapons into the US\" either across the Mexican border or using a small transport missile that can slip though undetected when launched from a Russian airplane.<ref name=\"Lunev\"/> Searches of the areas identified by Lunev – who admits he never planted any weapons in the US – have been conducted, \"but law-enforcement officials have never found such weapons caches, with or without portable nuclear weapons\" in the US.<ref>Steve Goldstein and Chris Mondics, \"Some Weldon-backed allegations unconfirmed; Among them: A plot to crash planes into a reactor, and missing suitcase-size Soviet atomic weapons.\" ''Philadelphia Inquirer'' (15 March 2006) A7.</ref>
In a 2004 interview, colonel general of [[Strategic Missile Forces
column2: RVSN]] [[Viktor Esin]] said that Soviet small-scale nuclear bombs have only been operated by the Army. All such devices have been stored in a weapons depot within Russia, and only left it for checks at the plant which produced them.<ref>{{cite news

column1: Soviet program of [[biological weapon]]s was initially developed by the

column2: Ministry of Defense of the Soviet Union]] (between 1945 and 1973).<ref name=\"Alibek\">Alibek, K. and S. Handelman. Biohazard: The Chilling True Story of the Largest Covert Biological Weapons Program in the World– Told from Inside by the Man Who Ran it. Delta (2000) {{ISBN

column1: The Soviet Union signed the [[Biological Weapons Convention]] on April 10, 1972 and ratified the treaty on March 26, 1975. However, it subsequently augmented its biowarfare programs. After 1975, the program of biological weapons was run primarily by the \"civilian\" [[Biopreparat]] agency, although it also included numerous facilities run by the  Soviet Ministry of Defense, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Chemical Industry, Ministry of Health, and [[Soviet Academy of Sciences]].<ref name=\"Alibek\"/>

According to [[Ken Alibek]], who was deputy-director of [[Biopreparat]], the Soviet biological weapons agency, and who defected to the United States in 1992, weapons were developed in labs in isolated areas of the Soviet Union including mobilization facilities at [[Omutininsk]], [[Penza]] and [[Pokrov, Vladimir Oblast
column2: Pokrov]] and research facilities at [[Moscow]], [[Stirzhi]] and [[Vladimir, Russia
column3: Vladimir]]. These weapons were tested at several facilities most often at \"Rebirth Island\" ([[Vozrozhdeniya]]) in the [[Aral Sea]] by firing the weapons into the air above monkeys tied to posts, the monkeys would then be monitored to determine the effects. According to Alibek, although Soviet offensive program was officially ended in 1992, Russia may be still involved in the activities prohibited by BWC.<ref name=\"Alibek\"/>

column1: In 1993, the story about the [[Sverdlovsk anthrax leak]] was published in Russia. The incident occurred when [[spore]]s of [[anthrax]] were accidentally released from a military facility in the city of Sverdlovsk (formerly, and now again, [[Yekaterinburg]]) {{convert
column4: abbr=on}} east of Moscow on April 2, 1979. The ensuing outbreak of the disease resulted in 94 people becoming infected, 64 of whom died over a period of six weeks.<ref name=\"Alibek\"/>

column1: Russia signed the [[Chemical Weapons Convention]] on January 13, 1993, and ratified it on November 5, 1997. Russia declared an arsenal of 39,967 tons of [[Chemical warfare
Ratification was followed by three years of inaction on chemical weapons destruction because of the [[August 1998 Russian financial crisis]].

Russia met its treaty obligations by destroying 1% of its chemical agents by the Chemical Weapons Convention's 2002 deadline,<ref>[http://www.opcw.org/html/global/ra_frameset.html News<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive
column3: date=April 6, 2004 }}</ref> but requested technical and financial assistance and extensions on the deadlines of 2004 and 2007 due to the environmental challenges of chemical disposal. This extension procedure spelled out in the treaty has been utilized by other countries, including the [[United States and weapons of mass destruction#Chemical weapons disposal
column4: United States]]. The extended deadline for complete destruction (April 2012) was not met.<ref name=sixty>[http://www.opcw.org/nc/news/article/global-campaign-to-destroy-chemical-weapons-passes-60-percent-mark/ Global Campaign to Destroy Chemical Weapons Passes 60 Percent Mark]. [[OPCW]]. 8 July 2010 (Accessed 19 August 2010)</ref> As of October 2011, Russia has destroyed 57% of its stockpile. Russia also destroyed all of its declared Category 2 (10,616 MTs) and Category 3 chemicals.<ref name=CSP16 />

column1: Russia  has stored its chemical weapons (or the required chemicals) which it declared within the CWC at 8 locations: in [[Gorny, Krasnopartizansky District, Saratov Oblast
column2: Gorny]] ([[Saratov Oblast]]) (2.9% of the declared stockpile by mass) and [[Kambarka]] ([[Udmurtia
column3: Udmurt Republic]]) (15.9%) stockpiles already have been destroyed. In [[Shchuchye, Kurgan Oblast
column4: Shchuchye]] ([[Kurgan Oblast]]) (13.6%), [[Maradykovsky]] ([[Kirov Oblast]]) (17.4%) and [[Leonidovka]] ([[Penza Oblast]]) (17.2%) destruction takes place, while installations are under construction in [[Pochep, Bryansk Oblast

column1: On 27 September 2017, OPCW announced that Russia had destroyed its entire chemical weapons stockpile.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=US long overdue destroying its chemical weapons, Putin says as Russia completes disposal (VIDEO)

column1: A range of Novichok agents were developed and tested in the 1970s and 1980s, but the intended Novichok weapons production site at the Pavlodar Chemical Plant in [[Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic
column2: Soviet Kazakhstan]] was still under construction when it was decided to demolish the chemical weapons building in 1987 in view of the forthcoming [[Chemical Weapons Convention]].<ref name=nti-201504>{{cite web
column9: title=The Pavlodar Chemical Weapons Plant in Kazakhstan: History and Legacy

column2: GRU]] agent [[Sergei Skripal]] and his daughter [[Poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal
column3: were poisoned]] in [[Salisbury]], [[United Kingdom]] by a chemical agent later confirmed to be Novichok.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Inspectors back UK in spy poisoning row
column8: via=www.bbc.com}}</ref> The incident raised new controversy over Russia's potential production and use of chemical weapons, with the United Kingdom accusing the Russian government or rogue Russian agents of orchestrating the attack, a claim Russia repeatedly denied.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=The curious case of Yulia Skripal's recorded phone call - DW - 06.04.2018

column2: Gorny]] in [[Saratov Oblast]], [[Kambarka]] in [[Udmurtia]], Leonidovka [[Penza Oblast]], Maradykovsky in [[Kirov Oblast]],  [[Shchuchye, Shchuchansky District, Kurgan Oblast

column1: According to the [[Federation of American Scientists]], an organization that assesses nuclear weapon stockpiles, as of 2018, the [[Russia
column2: Russian Federation]] possesses approximately 6,500 nuclear warheads.<ref name=FAS/>.\"<ref name=\"autogenerated1\">{{cite web
column4: title=Federation of American Scientists :: Status of World Nuclear Forces<!-- Bot generated title -->
column5: publisher=}}</ref> In addition to nuclear weapons, Russia declared an arsenal of 39,967 tons of [[chemical weapon]]s in 1997.<ref name=\"NTIchem\" /><ref name=\"CSP16\">{{cite web
column7: title=Opening Statement by the Director-General to the Conference of the States Parties at its Sixteenth Session
column10: publisher=[[OPCW]]}}</ref> The [[Soviet Union]] ratified the [[Geneva Protocol]] on April 5, 1928 with reservations. The reservations were dropped on January 18, 2001. Russia is also party to the [[Biological Weapons Convention]] and the [[Chemical Weapons Convention]]. The Soviet Union had a peak stockpile of 45,000 nuclear warheads in 1986.<ref name=\"NorrisKristensenGlobal\">Robert S. Norris and Hans M. Kristensen, \"[http://thebulletin.metapress.com/content/c4120650912x74k7/fulltext.pdf Global nuclear stockpiles, 1945-2006],\" Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists 62, no. 4 (July/August 2006), 64-66.</ref> It is estimated that from 1949 to 1991 the Soviet Union produced approximately 55,000 nuclear warheads.<ref>{{cite web
column15: date=December 1993}}</ref> In early 2019, more than 90% of the world's 13,865 [[List of states with nuclear weapons
column16: nuclear weapons]] were owned by Russia and the United States.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Global Nuclear Arsenal Declines, But Future Cuts Uncertain Amid U.S.-Russia Tensions

column1: At the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union
column2: dissolution]] of the [[Soviet Union]] in 1991, Soviet nuclear weapons were deployed in four of the new republics: Russia, [[Ukraine]], [[Belarus]] and [[Kazakhstan]]. In May 1992, these four states signed the [[Lisbon Protocol]], agreeing to join the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]], with Russia the [[successor state]] to the Soviet Union as a nuclear state, and the other three states joining as non-nuclear states.

column1: Ukraine agreed to give up its weapons to Russia, in exchange for guarantees of Ukrainian territory from Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States, known as the [[Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances]]. China and France also made statements in support of the memorandum.<ref>{{cite web

The exact number of nuclear warheads is a state secret and is therefore a matter of guesswork. The [[Federation of American Scientists]] estimates that Russia possesses 6,500 nuclear weapons, while the United States has 6,185; Russia and the U.S. each have 1,600 active deployed strategic nuclear warheads.<ref name=FAS/><ref>{{cite journal
column3: journal = Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists

column1: During an annual state-of-the-nation address given on March 1, 2018, President [[Vladimir Putin]] publicly claimed that Russia was now in possession of several new classes of nuclear weapons, including some with capabilities previously speculated to exist. Putin discussed several new or upgraded weapons, including a [[Boost-glide
column2: hypersonic glide vehicle]] known as the [[Avangard (hypersonic glide vehicle)
column3: Avangard]] capable of performing sharp maneuvers while traveling at 20 times the speed of sound making it \"absolutely invulnerable for any missile defense system.\" <ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/putin-boasts-russian-nuclear-weapons-53433951]{{dead link
column4: date=June 2019}}</ref> Putin also discussed the existence of a nuclear powered underwater torpedo and a nuclear powered [[cruise missile]] ([[9M730 Burevestnik]]), both with effectively unlimited range. He also discussed that Russia had tested a new class of traditional ICBM called the Sarmat, which expanded upon the range and carrying capability of the Soviet-era Satan ICBM. Animations of these weapons were shown in front of the live and televised audience, and Putin suggested that an online poll be conducted to give them official public names.<ref>{{cite web

column1: According to a Russian military doctrine stated in 2010, nuclear weapons could be used by Russia \"in response to the use of nuclear and other types of weapons of mass destruction against it or its allies, and also in case of aggression against Russia with the use of conventional weapons when the very existence of the state is threatened\".<ref name=\"rus_mil_doc\">[http://www.kremlin.ru/ref_notes/461 Russian military doctrine] (in Russian)</ref> Most military analysts believe that, in this case, Russia would pursue an 'escalate to de-escalate’ strategy, initiating limited nuclear exchange to bring adversaries to the negotiating table. Russia will also threaten nuclear conflict to discourage initial escalation of any major conventional conflict.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Getting Russia's nuclear strategy mostly right
Large stockpile with global range (dark blue)]]

column1: After the [[Korean War]], the [[Soviet Union]] transferred nuclear technology and weapons to the [[People's Republic of China]] as an adversary of the United States and [[NATO]]. According to [[Ion Mihai Pacepa]], \"Khrushchev's nuclear-proliferation process started with Communist China in April 1955, when the new ruler in the Kremlin consented to supply Beijing a sample atomic bomb and to help with its mass production. Subsequently, the Soviet Union built all the essentials of China's new military nuclear industry.\"<ref name=\"bomb\">[http://article.nationalreview.com/?q=YmU3NjM4ZTg3NjViMTUyNWJmYWYzMDE4ZmRhOTQxZmI= Tyrants and the Bomb] {{webarchive
column3: date=June 6, 2009 }} - by [[Ion Mihai Pacepa]], ''[[National Review]]'', October 17, 2006</ref>

column1: Russia is one of the five \"Nuclear Weapons States\" (NWS) under the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]] (NPT), which Russia ratified (as the [[Soviet Union]]) in 1968.

Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, a number of Soviet-era nuclear warheads remained on the territories of Belarus, Ukraine, and Kazakhstan. Under the terms of the [[Lisbon Protocol]] to the NPT, and following the 1995 Trilateral Agreement between Russia, Belarus, and the USA, these were transferred to Russia, leaving Russia as the sole inheritor of the Soviet nuclear arsenal. It is estimated that the Soviet Union had approximately 45,000 nuclear weapons stockpiled at the time of its collapse.

The collapse of the Soviet Union allowed for a warming of relations with NATO. Fears of a [[nuclear holocaust]] lessened. In September 1997, the former secretary of the Russian Security Council Alexander Lebed claimed 100 \"suitcase sized\" nuclear weapons were unaccounted for. He said he was attempting to inventory the weapons when he was fired by President Boris Yeltsin in October 1996.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Russian Officials Deny Claims Of Missing Nuclear Weapons
column5: accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> Indeed, several US politicians have expressed worries and promised legislation addressing the threat.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Nuclear Dangers: Fear Increases of Terrorists Getting Hands on 'Loose' Warheads as Security Slips

column4: [[Dmitry Medvedev]] with [[Barack Obama]] after signing the [[New START]] treaty in Prague, 2010]]

column1: In 2002, the United States and Russia agreed to reduce their stockpiles to not more than 2,700 warheads each in the [[SORT]] treaty. In 2003, the US rejected Russian proposals to further reduce each nation's nuclear stockpiles to 1,500. Russia, in turn, refused to discuss reduction of [[tactical nuclear weapons]].<ref name=\"trenin\">[http://ifri.org/files/Securite_defense/prolif_paper_Trenin.pdf Russia's Nuclear Policy in the 21st Century Environment] {{webarchive
column3: date=February 27, 2008 }} - analysis by Dmitri Trenin, IFRI Proliferation Papers n°13, 2005</ref>

column1: After U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] withdrew from the 1972 [[Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty]], Russia responded by building-up their [[Russia and weapons of mass destruction#Nuclear weapons
column2: nuclear capabilities]], in such a way as to counterbalance U.S. capabilities.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Russia's Nuclear Weapons Buildup Is Aimed at Beating U.S. Missile Defenses

column1: Russia decided not to sign the UN treaty on the [[Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons
column2: Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons]], which was adopted on 7 July 2017 by 122 States.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=122 countries adopt 'historic' UN treaty to ban nuclear weapons

column1: Most analysts agree that Russia’s nuclear strategy under Putin eventually brought it into violation of the 1987 [[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty]] (although this is not confirmed).<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Russia may have violated the INF Treaty. Here's how the United States appears to have done the same.
column6: language=en-US}}</ref> According to Russian officials, the American decision to deploy [[United States national missile defense
column7: the missile defense system]] in Europe was a violation of the treaty.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Russia Calls New U.S. Missile Defense System a 'Direct Threat'
column13: publisher=NYT}}</ref> U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] announced on 20 October 2018 that the U.S. would no longer consider itself bound by the treaty’s provisions, raising nuclear tensions between the two powers.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Russia Violated an Arms Treaty. Trump Ditched It, Making the Nuclear Threat Even Worse.

column1: There were allegations that Russia contributed to [[North Korean nuclear program]], selling it the equipment for the safe storage and transportation of nuclear materials.<ref name=\"Korea\">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/1523468/Russia-secretly-offered-North-Korea-nuclear-technology.html Russia secretly offered North Korea nuclear technology] - by a Special Correspondent in Pyongyang and Michael Hirst, ''Telegraph'', September 7, 2006.</ref> Nevertheless, Russia condemned North Korean nuclear tests since then.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Russia expresses serious concern over DPRK nuke issue

column1: According to high-ranking Russian [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)
column3: Sergei Tretyakov]], a businessman told him that he keeps his own nuclear bomb at his [[dacha]] outside [[Moscow]].<ref name=\"Comrade J\">Pete Earley, \"Comrade J: The Untold Secrets of Russia's Master Spy in America After the End of the Cold War\", Penguin Books, 2007, {{ISBN

column1: Russia is allegedly making efforts to build its influential hold in Africa for earning several billions pounds by selling nuclear technology to developing African countries.<ref>{{cite_web
column3: title=Guardian: Russia pushing 'unsuitable' nuclear power in Africa

column2: GRU]] defector [[Stanislav Lunev]] described alleged Soviet plans for using [[tactical nuclear weapons]] for [[sabotage]] against the United States in the event of war. He described Soviet-made [[suitcase nukes]] identified as RA-115s (or RA-115-01s for submersible weapons) which weigh from fifty to sixty pounds (23 kg - 27 kg). These portable bombs can last for many years if wired to an electric source. \"In case there is a loss of power, there is a battery backup. If the battery runs low, the weapon has a transmitter that sends a coded message – either by satellite or directly to a GRU post at a Russian embassy or consulate.\".<ref name=\"Lunev\">[[Stanislav Lunev]]. ''Through the Eyes of the Enemy: The Autobiography of Stanislav Lunev'', Regnery Publishing, Inc., 1998. {{ISBN

column1: Lunev was personally looking for hiding places for weapons caches in the [[Shenandoah Valley]] area.<ref name=\"Lunev\"/> He said that \"it is surprisingly easy to smuggle nuclear weapons into the US\" either across the Mexican border or using a small transport missile that can slip though undetected when launched from a Russian airplane.<ref name=\"Lunev\"/> Searches of the areas identified by Lunev – who admits he never planted any weapons in the US – have been conducted, \"but law-enforcement officials have never found such weapons caches, with or without portable nuclear weapons\" in the US.<ref>Steve Goldstein and Chris Mondics, \"Some Weldon-backed allegations unconfirmed; Among them: A plot to crash planes into a reactor, and missing suitcase-size Soviet atomic weapons.\" ''Philadelphia Inquirer'' (15 March 2006) A7.</ref>
In 2004 interview, colonel general of [[Strategic Missile Forces
column2: RVSN]] [[Viktor Esin]] said that Soviet small-scale nuclear bombs have only been operated by the Army. All such devices have been stored in a weapons depot within Russia, and only left it for checks at the plant which produced them.<ref>{{cite news

column1: Soviet program of [[biological weapon]]s was initially developed by the

column2: Ministry of Defense of the Soviet Union]] (between 1945 and 1973).<ref name=\"Alibek\">Alibek, K. and S. Handelman. Biohazard: The Chilling True Story of the Largest Covert Biological Weapons Program in the World– Told from Inside by the Man Who Ran it. Delta (2000) {{ISBN

column1: The Soviet Union signed the [[Biological Weapons Convention]] on April 10, 1972 and ratified the treaty on March 26, 1975. However, it subsequently augmented its biowarfare programs. After 1975, the program of biological weapons was run primarily by the \"civilian\" [[Biopreparat]] agency, although it also included numerous facilities run by the  Soviet Ministry of Defense, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Chemical Industry, Ministry of Health, and [[Soviet Academy of Sciences]].<ref name=\"Alibek\"/>

According to [[Ken Alibek]], who was deputy-director of [[Biopreparat]], the Soviet biological weapons agency, and who defected to the United States in 1992, weapons were developed in labs in isolated areas of the Soviet Union including mobilization facilities at [[Omutininsk]], [[Penza]] and [[Pokrov, Vladimir Oblast
column2: Pokrov]] and research facilities at [[Moscow]], [[Stirzhi]] and [[Vladimir, Russia
column3: Vladimir]]. These weapons were tested at several facilities most often at \"Rebirth Island\" ([[Vozrozhdeniya]]) in the [[Aral Sea]] by firing the weapons into the air above monkeys tied to posts, the monkeys would then be monitored to determine the effects. According to Alibek, although Soviet offensive program was officially ended in 1992, Russia may be still involved in the activities prohibited by BWC.<ref name=\"Alibek\"/>

column8: via=www.bbc.com}}</ref> The incident raised new controversy over Russia's potential production and use of chemical weapons, with the United Kingdom accusing the Russian government or rogue Russian agents of orchestrating the attack, a claim Russia repeatedly denied.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=The curious case of Yulia Skripal's recorded phone call - DW - 06.04.2018

column1: Russia has a number of factories for destruction of its chemical weapons arsenal: [[Gorny, Krasnopartizansky District, Saratov Oblast
column2: Gorny]] in [[Saratov Oblast]], [[Kambarka]] in [[Udmurtia]], Leonidovka [[Penza Oblast]], Maradykovsky in [[Kirov Oblast]],  [[Shchuchye, Shchuchansky District, Kurgan Oblast
column3: Shchuchye]] in [[Kurgan Oblast]] and the latest one [[Pochep, Bryansk Oblast
column4: Pochep]] in the [[Bryansk Oblast]] 70 km from the [[Russia–Ukraine border
column5: border with Ukraine]], built with funds from Italy in accordance with the agreement signed between the two countries.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=\"Russia opens new chemical weapons destruction plant\", RIA Novosti, November 2010
column11: title=Italy to help Russia destroy chemical weapons
column13: accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> The last Russian chemical disposal facility in [[Kizner (settlement)
column14: Kizner]], [[Udmurtia]], was opened on December 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=New Chemical Weapons Destruction Facility Opens at Kizner in the Russian Federation

column1: Wang Yibo was born on 5 August 1997 in [[Luoyang]], [[Henan]], [[China]]. He started dancing when he was young and in 2011, during his second year in secondary school, Wang participated in IBD dance competition. Emerging as top sixteen in the hip-hop category, he then became a trainee of [[Yuehua Entertainment]].<ref>{{cite web
