Kurdish]] Sheikh, Jalaleddin, led thousands of soldiers to massacre the Armenians of the province and destroyed and plundered many of their villages.<ref>[https://www.sophenearmeniaca.com/2019/03/06/who-was-sheikh-jalaleddin/ Who Was Sheikh Jalaleddin?]</ref> These events are characterized in the non-fiction book ''Armenia and the Campaign of 1877'' by British war correspondent Charles B. Norman and in the fictional novella [[Jalaleddin (novella)
column4: Raffi]] in very similar terms.<ref>[https://www.sophenearmeniaca.com/2019/01/06/jalaleddin-and-the-russo-turkish-war-of-1877-1878/ Jalaleddin and the Russo-Turkish War of 1877-1878]</ref>

column5: Ruins of the old walled city of Van seen from the castle rock.]]

column1: The province's Armenian population was devastated during [[Armenian Genocide]] by the [[Young Turks]].<ref>Akcam, Taner. ''A Shameful Act'', p. 140. New York:Henry Holt Co. 2006. {{ISBN
column2: 0-8050-8665-X}}</ref> The regional administrator, [[Cevdet Bey]], was reported to have said that \"We have cleansed the Armenians and Syriac [Christian]s from [[Azerbaijan (Iran)
column3: Azerbaijan]], and we will do the same in Van.<ref name=\"Akçam, 201\">Akçam, 201</ref> Numerous reports from Ottoman officials, such as a parliament deputy, the governor of [[Aleppo]] as well as the German consul in Van, suggested that deliberate provocations against the Armenians were being orchestrated by the local government.<ref name=\"Akçam, 201\"/> In mid-April 1915, Cevdet Bey ordered the execution of four Armenian leaders,<ref>Morgenthau, Henry. ''Ambassador Morgenthau's Story'', p. 205. Wayne State University Press, 2003. {{ISBN
column4: 0-8143-2979-9}}</ref><ref>Ussher, Clarence Douglass. ''An American Physician in Turkey''. New York: Houghton Mifflin Company, 1917, p. 236.</ref> which drove the Armenians to take up arms in self-defense.<ref>Ter Minassian, Anahide, \"Van 1915\" in ''Armenian Van/Vaspurakan'', pp. 209–44.</ref> On the other hand, writer and genocide scholar [[Taner Akçam]] acknowledges that in the case of Van, the deportations may have been driven by military necessity<ref>Akçam, p. 202.</ref> and states the resistance in Van should be examined as a separate case.<ref>Akçam, p. 200</ref>

column1: Some scholars explain that the [[Armenian resistance during World War I
column2: Armenians launched a rebellion]] at Van in 1915, lured by Russian promises of independence. Other scholars argue that the Armenian residents, hoping to avoid the slaughter being inflicted on the rural populations surrounding Van, defended themselves in the Armenian quarters of the city against the Turks.<ref name=\"gens\">The Banality of Indifference: Zionism and the Armenian Genocide – Page 42 by Yaïr Auron</ref> The Russians finally relieved the Armenian defenders of Van in late May 1915. In August, a victory over the Russian army allowed the Ottoman army to retake Van. In September 1915, the Russians forced the Turks out of Van for the second time. Russian forces began to leave the area after the [[October Revolution]] in Russia in 1917, and by April 1918, it was recaptured by the Ottoman army. According to Taner Akçam, citing the ''Osmanli Belgelerinde Ermeniler 1915–1920'' (Armenians in Ottoman Documents, 1915–1920), after the Turks took back the city from the Russians, they killed all Armenians in the city.<ref>Akçam, p. 140</ref> [[Clarence Ussher]], an American physician and missionary in Van, and an eye-witness to the events, reported that 55,000 Armenians had been killed.<ref>{{cite book
column19: isbn=9780739135907}}</ref> The end of World War I forced the Ottoman army to surrender its claim to Van, although it stayed in Turkish hands following the [[Turkish War of Independence]].

column5: The center of modern Van seen from the castle rock]]

column1: In the [[Treaty of Sèvres]], the [[Allies of World War I
column2: Entente Powers]] decided to cede the city to the [[First Republic of Armenia]]. [[Turkish revolutionaries]], led by [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] rejected the terms of the treaty and instead waged the [[Turkish War of Independence]].  However the idea of ceding Van to the Armenians was floated, and Ismet Inonu was said to have surveyed army officers on 14 October 1919 on the issue of ceding Van and Bitlis. However the parliament in Ankara rejected any compromise on this issue.<ref>Akçam, Taner. \"A shameful Act.\" Translated by Paul Bessemer. Metropolitan Books, New York. 2006.</ref>{{Page needed
column3: date=September 2010}} By 1920, Van fell under Turkish control again and its remaining Armenian inhabitants were expelled in a final round of [[ethnic cleansing]].<ref name=\"gens\"/> With the [[Treaty of Lausanne]] and [[Treaty of Kars]], the Treaty of Sèvres was annulled and Van remained de facto under Turkish sovereignty.

column1: By the end of the conflicts, the town of Van was empty and in ruins. The city was rebuilt after the war a few kilometers east of the ancient citadel, which is now known as [[Van Castle]] (''Van Kalesi''). The city now lies at about {{convert
The current acting Mayor of the city is the Governor of the Province Van, Mehmet Emin Bilmez. The [[2019 Turkish local elections
column2: local elections]] in March 2019 won Bedia Özgökçe Ertan and she acted as the Mayor until August 2019, when she was dismissed due to accusations for supporting terrorism.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Metropolitan Mayors of Diyarbakir, Mardin and Van removed from office

column1: Van has a harsh [[humid continental climate
column2: continental climate]] with cold, snowy winters and warm, dry summers. Rainfall occurs mostly during the spring and autumn. Under [[Köppen climate classification
column3: Köppen's climate classification]] Van features a hot dry summer subtype (Köppen: ''Dsa'') of the [[humid continental climate]].

column2: source 1= Devlet Meteoroloji İşleri Genel Müdürlüğü [http://www.dmi.gov.tr/veridegerlendirme/il-ve-ilceler-istatistik.aspx?m=VAN]

column1: The modern city is located on the plain extending from the [[Lake Van]], at a distance of {{convert

Van has often been called \"The Pearl of the East\" because of the beauty of its surrounding landscape. An old Armenian proverb in the same sense is \"Van in this world, paradise in the next.\"<ref>{{Cite book
column8: pages = 207 }}</ref> This phrase has been slightly modified in Turkish as ''dünyada Van, ahirette iman'' or \"Van for this world, faith for the next.\"

column1: The city is home to [[Van Yüzüncü Yıl Üniversitesi]] (''Van 100th Year University'') and recently came to the headlines for two highly publicized investigations initiated by the Prosecutor of Van, one of which was focused on accusations against the university's [[Rector (academia)
column2: rector]], Prof. [[Hasan Ceylan]], who was kept in custody for a time. He was finally acquitted but lost his rectorate. He is a grandson of [[Güllü Agop
column3: Agop Vartovyan]], an Ottoman Armenian who is accepted as the founder of modern Turkish theatre. Prof. Hasan Ceylan is also the department chairman of Environmental Engineering in the Van 100th Year University.

column1: In 1941, Van suffered a destructive [[1941 Van–Erciş earthquake
column2: 5.9 M<sub>w</sub> earthquake]]. A more severe [[2011 Van earthquake
column3: 7.2 M<sub>w</sub> earthquake]] occurred on October 23, 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = Report: Death toll rises to 217 after massive earthquake in Turkey
column8: publisher=CNN}}</ref> On November 9, 2011, a 5.7 magnitude earthquake caused several buildings to collapse.

column1: In culinary terms, as some cities in Turkey became renowned for their [[kebap]] culture or other types of traditional local dishes, Van has distinguished itself with its breakfast culture.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Turkish city that lives for breakfast
column7: access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref> You can find all sorts of food in Van, but pides are in all of their meals.

column1: Van stands on Highway D300, which runs from the Iranian border 100 km east at Kapikoy through Van then along the south lake shore to [[Tatvan]] (100 km), and westwards to the rest of Turkey. Highway D975 runs north to Dogubeyazit and south towards Hakkari. Frequent buses and dolmuses ply these highways.

Van is the western terminus of the railway line from Iran, with freight and passenger trains (suspended between 2015 and 2018). There is a [[train ferry]] (upgraded in 2015) across the lake to Tatvan. There is no railway around the lake; it is intended eventually to build one but to date there are no plans. This would actually create an unbroken rail link between Europe and the Indian subcontinent, as Tatvan is the terminus of the line to Ankara and Istanbul.
Van has daily flights to Istanbul, Ankara and other major Turkish cities from  [[Van Ferit Melen Airport
Near Van, there is a [[longwave]] broadcasting station with a {{convert
column7: -tall}} guyed mast. It went in service in 1990 and operates on 225 kHz with 600 kW. It has also local news outlets like ''Van Gazetesi'' or ''Gazete Van.''<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=VAN HAVADİS GAZETESİ {{!}} Van Haber, Son Dakika, Van Haberleri
column15: website=Türkiye'nin Uluslararası Haber Sitesi ve Gazetesi

The term '''Dirac matter''' refers to a class of [[condensed matter]] systems which can be effectively described by the [[Dirac equation]]. Even though the [[Dirac equation]] itself was formulated for [[fermions]], the quasi-particles present within Dirac matter can be of any statistics. As a consequence, Dirac matter can be distinguished in [[fermionic]], [[bosonic]] or [[anyon]]ic Dirac matter. Prominent examples of Dirac matter are [[Graphene]], [[topological insulators]], Dirac semimetals, [[Weyl semimetal]]s, various [[high-temperature superconductors]] with <math>d</math>-wave pairing and [[Helium-3
column2: liquid Helium-3]]. The effective theory of such systems is classified by a specific choice of the [[Dirac mass]], the Dirac velocity, the [[Dirac matrices]] and the [[space-time curvature]]. The universal treatment of the class of Dirac matter in terms of an effective theory leads to a common features with respect to the [[density of states]], the [[heat capacity]] and impurity scattering.

column1: Members of the class of Dirac matter differ significantly in nature. However, all examples of Dirac matter are unified by similarities within the algebraic structure of an effective theory describing them.
The general definition of Dirac matter is a condensed matter system where the [[quasi-particle]] excitations can be described in curved spacetime by the generalised Dirac equation:

In the above definition <math>d_\\mu</math> denotes a [[covariant vector]] depending on the <math>(d+1)</math>-dimensional momentum <math>p</math> (<math>d</math> space <math>+ 1</math> time dimension), <math>e_a^\\mu</math> is the [[vierbein]] describing the curvature of the space, <math>m</math> the [[quasi-particle]] mass and <math>v_D</math> the Dirac velocity. Note that since in Dirac matter the Dirac equation gives the effective theory of the quasiparticles, the energy from the mass term is <math>m v_D^2</math>, not the rest mass <math>m c^2</math> of a massive particle. <math>\\gamma^\\mu</math> refers to a set of [[Dirac matrices]], where the defining for the construction is given by the anticommutation relation,
<math>\\eta^{\\mu\\nu}</math> is the [[Minkowski metric]] with signature (+ - - -) and <math>I_d</math> is the <math>d\\times d</math>-dimensional unit matrix.

In all equations, implicit summation over <math>a</math> and <math>\\mu</math> is used ([[Einstein convention]]). Furthermore, <math>\\Psi</math> is the [[wavefunction]]. The unifying feature of all Dirac matter is the matrix structure of the equation describing the quasi-particle excitations.

In the limit where <math>d_\\mu(p) = D_\\mu</math>, i.e. the [[covariant derivative]], conventional Dirac matter is obtained. However, this general definition allows the description of matter with higher order dispersion relations and in curved spacetime as long as the effective [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)
column3: matrix]] structure specific to the [[Dirac equation]].

column1: The majority of experimental realisations of Dirac matter to date are in the limit of <math>d_\\mu (p) = D_\\mu</math> which therefore defines conventional Dirac matter in which the quasiparticles are described by the [[Dirac equation in curved spacetime

Here, <math>D_\\mu</math> denotes the [[covariant derivative]]. As an example, for the flat metric, the energy of a free Dirac particle differs significantly from the classical kinetic energy where energy is proportional to momentum squared:

The Dirac velocity <math>v_D</math> gives the gradient of the <math>E-k</math> dispersion at large momenta <math>k</math>, <math>m</math> is the mass of particle or object. In the case of massless Dirac matter, such as the fermionic quasiparticles in [[graphene]] or [[Weyl semimetal]]s, the energy-momentum relation is linear,

Therefore, conventional Dirac matter includes all systems that have a linear crossing or linear behavior in some region of the energy-momentum relation. They are characterised by features that resemble an 'X', sometimes tilted or skewed and sometimes with a gap between the upper <math>\\vee</math> and lower <math>\\wedge</math> parts (the turning points of which become rounded if the origin of the gap is a mass term).
The general features and some specific examples of conventional Dirac matter are discussed in the following sections.
=== Technological relevance and tuning of Dirac matter ===

column3: Tuning of Dirac matter: As the density of states is well defined, the density of states at the Fermi level (for fermionic Dirac matter) can be nicely tuned by shifting the chemical potential <math>\\mu</math>. Additionally, introducing a mass term <math>m</math> leads to a gap between the two cones and the dispersion becomes quadratic near <math>k=0</math>.]]

column1: Dirac matter, especially fermionic Dirac matter has much potential for technological applications. For example, 2010's [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] was awarded to [[Andre Geim]] and [[Konstantin Novoselov]] \"for groundbreaking experiments regarding the material graphene\". Within the official press release of the [[Swedish Royal Academy of Science]] it is stated that<ref name=\"nobelprize\">[https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/2010/press.pdf The Nobel Prize in Physics 2010]</ref>

[...] a vast variety of practical applications now appear possible including the creation of new materials and the manufacture of innovative electronics. Graphene transistors are predicted to be substantially faster than today’s silicon transistors and result in more efficient computers.
In general, the properties of massless fermionic Dirac matter can be controlled by shifting the [[chemical potential]] by means of [[doping (semiconductor)
column3: field effect]] setup. By tuning the [[chemical potential]], it is possible to have a precise control of the number of states present, since the [[density of states]] varies in a well-defined way with energy.

column1: Additionally, depending on the specific realization of the Dirac material, it may be possible to introduce a mass term <math>m</math> that opens a gap in the spectrum - a [[band gap]]. In general, the mass term is the result of breaking a specific symmetry of the system. The size of the [[band gap]] can be controlled precisely by controlling the strength of the mass term.
The [[density of states]] of <math>d</math>-dimensional Dirac matter near the Dirac point scales as <math>N(\\epsilon)\\propto
column3: ^{d-1}</math> where <math>\\epsilon</math> is the particle energy.<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\">{{cite journal
column17: arxiv=1405.5774}}</ref> The vanishing density of states for quasiparticles in Dirac matter mimics [[semimetal]] physics for physical dimension <math>d>1</math>. In the two-dimensional systems such as graphene and topological insulators, the density of states gives a V shape, compared with the constant value for massive particles with dispersion <math>E=k^2/2m</math>.

column1: Experimental measurement of the density of states near the Dirac point by standard techniques such as scanning tunnelling microscopy often differ from the theoretical form due to the effects of disorder and interactions.<ref name=\"principi2011tunneling\">{{cite journal
column3: title=The tunneling density-of-states of interacting massless Dirac fermions

column1: Specific heat, the [[heat capacity]] per unit mass, describes the energy required to change the temperature of a sample. The low-temperature electronic [[specific heat]] of Dirac matter is <math>C(T\\to 0)\\sim T^d</math> which is different from <math>C(T\\to 0)\\sim T</math> encountered for normal metals.<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\"/> Therefore, for systems whose physical dimension is greater than 1, the specific heat can provide a clear signature of the underlying Dirac nature of the quasiparticles.

[[Landau quantization]] refers to the quantization of the cyclotron orbits of charged particles in magnetic fields. As a result, the charged particles can only occupy orbits with discrete energy values, called Landau levels. For 2-dimensional systems with a perpendicular magnetic field, the energy for Landau-levels for ordinary matter described the Schrödinger equation and Dirac matter are given by<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\"/>

Here, <math>\\omega_c</math> is the [[cyclotron frequency]] which is linearly dependent of the applied magnetic field and the charge of the particle. There are two distinct features between the Landau level quantization for 2D Schrödinger fermions (ordinary matter) and 2D Dirac fermions. First, the energy for Schrödinger fermions is linearly dependent with respect to the integer quantum number <math>n</math>, whereas it exhibits a square-root dependence for the Dirac fermions. This key difference plays an important role in the experimental verification of Dirac matter.<ref name=\"novoselov2005two\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Two-dimensional gas of massless Dirac fermions in graphene
column30: title=Observation of Landau levels of Dirac fermions in graphite
column41: bibcode=2007NatPh...3..623L}}</ref> Furthermore, for <math>n=0</math> there exists a 0 energy level for Dirac fermions which is independent of the cyclotron frequency <math>\\omega_c</math> and with that of the applied magnetic field. For example, the existence of the zeroth Landau level gives rise to a [[quantum Hall effect]] where the Hall conductance in quantized at half-integer values.<ref name=\"chen2008charged\">{{cite journal

column1: In the context of Fermionic quasiparticles, the Dirac velocity is identical to the Fermi velocity; in bosonic systems, no Fermi velocity exists, so the Dirac velocity is a more general property of such systems.
[[Graphene]] is a 2-dimensional crystalline [[allotrope]] of [[carbon]], where the carbon atoms are arranged on a [[hexagonal lattice]].

Each carbon atom forms <math>\\sigma</math>-bonds to the three neighboring atoms that lie in the graphene plane at angles of 120<math>^\\circ</math>. These bonds are mediated by three of carbon's four [[electrons]] while the fourth electron, which occupies a <math>\\mathrm{p}_z</math> [[Atomic orbital
column3: {{pi}}-bond]] that leads to the [[Electronic band structure
column4: electronic bands]] at the [[Fermi level]]. The unique transport properties and the [[semimetal]]lic state of graphene are the result of the delocalized electrons occupying these p<math>_z</math> orbitals.<ref name=\"abergel2010properties\">{{cite journal
column6: title=Properties of graphene: A theoretical perspective

column1: The semimetallic state corresponds to a linear crossing of energy bands at the <math>K</math> and <math>K'</math> points of graphene's hexagonal [[Brillouin zone]]. At these two points, the electronic structure can be effectively described by the [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)
Here, <math>\\sigma_x</math> and <math>\\sigma_y</math> are two of the three [[Pauli matrices]].

The factor <math>\\tau=+/-</math> indicates whether the Hamiltonian describes is centred on the <math>K</math> or <math>K'</math> valley at the corner of hexagonal [[Brillouin zone]]. For graphene, the Dirac velocity is about <math>\\hbar v_D \\approx 5.8</math> eV <math>\\AA</math>.<ref name=\"abergel2010properties\"/> An energy gap in the dispersion of graphene can be obtained from a low-energy Hamiltionain of the form
which now contains a mass term <math>M</math>. There are several distinct ways of introducing a mass term, and the results have different characteristics.<ref name=\"haldane\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Model for a Quantum Hall Effect without Landau Levels: Condensed-Matter Realization of the \"Parity Anomaly\"
column16: title=Quantum Spin Hall Effect in Graphene
column27: bibcode=2005PhRvL..95v6801K}}</ref> The most practical approach for creating a gap (introducing a mass term) is to break the sublattice symmetry of the lattice where each carbon atom is slightly different to its nearest but identical to its next-nearest neighbours; an effect that may result from substrate effects.

column1: A [[topological insulator]] is a material that behaves as an insulator in its interior (bulk) but whose surface contains conducting states. This property represents a non-trivial, symmetry protected [[topological order]]. As a consequence, electrons in topological insulators can only move along the [[Interface (matter)
column2: surface]] of the material. In the bulk of a non-interacting topological insulator, the [[Fermi level]] is positioned within the gap between the [[valence and conduction bands
column3: conduction and valence bands]]. On the surface, there are special states within the bulk [[energy gap]] which can be effectively described by a Dirac Hamiltonian:

column1: where <math>\\hat{\\mathbf{z}}</math> is normal to the surface and <math>{\\mathbf{\\sigma}}</math> is in the real [[spin (physics)
column2: spin]] basis. However, if we rotate spin by a [[unitary operator]], <math>U={\\rm diag}[1,i]</math>, we will end up with the standard notation of Dirac Hamiltonian, <math>{\\cal H} = \\hbar v_{D} {\\mathbf{\\sigma}}\\cdot {\\mathbf{k}}</math>.

column1: Such Dirac cones emerging on the surface of 3-dimensional crystals were observed in experiment, e.g.: [[bismuth selenide]] (Bi<math>_2</math>Se<math>_3</math>),<ref name=\"xia2009observation\">{{cite journal
column3: title=Observation of a large-gap topological-insulator class with a single Dirac cone on the surface
column34: title=Experimental realization of a topological crystalline insulator in Sn ''Te''

column3: While they are gapped, near the <math>K</math> and <math>K^\\prime</math> points of their hexagonal Brilliouin zone, the dispersions of transition metal dichalcogenides can be described by a massive Dirac equation with additional spin-orbit coupling terms that lead to spin-splitting in the valence band.]]

column1: The low-energy properties some semiconducting [[transition metal dichalcogenide monolayers]],
can be described by a two-dimensional massive (gapped) Dirac Hamiltonian with an additional term describing a strong [[spin–orbit coupling]]:<ref name=\"Xiao12\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Coupled Spin and Valley Physics in Monolayers ofMoS2and Other Group-VI Dichalcogenides
column23: title=Effective lattice Hamiltonian for monolayer MoS2: Tailoring electronic structure with perpendicular electric and magnetic fields
column38: title=Monolayer MoS2: Trigonal warping, theΓvalley, and spin-orbit coupling effects
column59: title=Three-band tight-binding model for monolayers of group-VIB transition metal dichalcogenides

column1: The spin-orbit coupling <math>\\lambda</math> provides a large spin-splitting in the valence band and <math>s</math> indicates the [[spin (physics)
column2: spin]] degree of freedom. As for graphene, <math>\\tau</math> gives the valley degree of freedom - whether near the <math>K</math> or <math>K^\\prime</math> point of the hexagonal Brillouin zone. Transition metal dichalcogenide monolayers are often discussed in reference to potential applications in [[valleytronics]].

column1: [[Weyl semimetal]]s, for example tantalum arsenide (TaAs),<ref name=Huang>{{cite journal
column30: title=A Weyl Fermion semimetal with surface Fermi arcs in the transition metal monopnictide TaAs class
column40: title=Weyl Semimetal Phase in Noncentrosymmetric Transition-Metal Monophosphides
column100: title=Discovery of a Weyl Fermion semimetal and topological Fermi arcs
column112: title=Observation of the Chiral-Anomaly-Induced Negative Magnetoresistance in 3D Weyl Semimetal Ta ''As''
column147: title=New type of Weyl semimetal with quadratic double Weyl fermions
column148: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column188: bibcode=2016PNAS..113.1180H}}</ref> have a Hamiltonian that is very similar to that of graphene, but now includes all three Pauli matrices and the linear crossings occur in 3D:

column1: Since all three [[Pauli matrices]] are present, there is no further Pauli matrix that could open a gap in the spectrum and Weyl points are therefore [[topologically protected]].<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\"/> Tilting of the linear cones so the Dirac velocity varies leads to type II Weyl semimetals.<ref name=\"soluyanov2015type\">{{cite journal
One distinct, experimentally observable feature of Weyl semimetals is that the surface states form [[Fermi arc]]s since the [[Fermi surface]] does not form a closed loop.
In crystals that are symmetric under [[point reflection
column3: time reversal]], electronic energy bands are two-fold degenerate. This degeneracy is referred to as [[Kramers degeneracy]]. Therefore, semimetals with linear crossings of two energy bands (two-fold degeneracy) at the [[Fermi energy]] exhibit a four-fold degeneracy at the crossing point. The effective [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)
column4: Hamiltonian]] for these states can be written as

column1: This has exactly the matrix structure of Dirac matter. Examples of experimentally realised Dirac semimetals are [[Bismuth#Bismuthine and bismuthides
column4: title=Dirac semimetal and topological phase transitions inA3Bi (A=Na, K, Rb)
column30: title=Discovery of a Three-Dimensional Topological Dirac Semimetal, Na3Bi
column62: title=Observation of Fermi arc surface states in a topological metal
column106: title=Three-dimensional Dirac semimetal and quantum transport in Cd3As2

column2: title=Observation of a three-dimensional topological Dirac semimetal phase in high-mobility Cd3As2
column36: title=Experimental Realization of a Three-Dimensional Dirac Semimetal

column1: [[File:Dispersions for bosonic (left) and fermionic (right) Dirac materials.png
column3: Dispersions for bosonic (left) and fermionic (right) Dirac materials. In contrast to the fermionic case where Pauli exclusion confines excitations close to the Fermi energy, the description of boson requires the entire Brillioun zone.]]

column1: While historic interest focussed on fermionic quasiparticles that have potential for technological applications, particularly in electronics, the mathematical structure of the [[Dirac equation]] is not restricted to the [[Particle statistics
column2: statistics of the particles]]. This has led to recent development of the concept of bosonic Dirac matter.

column1: In the case of [[bosons]], there is no [[Pauli exclusion principle]] to confine excitations close to the [[chemical potential]] (Fermi energy for fermions) so the entire [[Brillouin zone]] must be included. At low temperatures, the bosons will collect at the lowest energy point, the <math>\\Gamma</math>-point of the lower band. Energy must be added to excite the quasiparticles to the vicinity of the linear crossing point.

Several examples of Dirac matter with fermionic quasi-particles occur in systems where there is a hexagonal crystal lattice; so bosonic quasiparticles on an hexagonal lattice are the natural candidates for bosonic Dirac matter. In fact, the underlying symmetry of a crystal structure strongly constrains and protects the emergence of linear band crossings. Typical bosonic [[quasiparticles]] in [[condensed matter]] are [[magnon]]s, [[phonons]], [[polaritons]] and [[plasmons]].

Existing examples of bosonic Dirac matter include transition metal [[halides]] such as CrX<math>_3</math> (X= Cl, Br, I), where the [[magnon]] spectrum exhibits linear crossings,<ref name=\"pershoguba2018dirac\">{{cite journal
column24: bibcode=2018PhRvX...8a1010P}}</ref> granular [[superconductors]] in a [[honeycomb lattice]] <ref name=\"Banerjee\">{{cite journal
column26: title=Granular superconductor in a honeycomb lattice as a realization of bosonic Dirac material
column43: bibcode=2016PhRvB..93m4502B}}</ref> and hexagonal arrays of [[semiconductor microcavities]] hosting [[microcavity polaritons]] with linear crossings.<ref name=\"jacqmin2014direct\">{{cite journal
column46: title=Direct Observation of Dirac Cones and a Flatband in a Honeycomb Lattice for Polaritons
column73: bibcode=2014PhRvL.112k6402J}}</ref> Like graphene, all these systems have an hexagonal lattice structure.

column1: Anyonic Dirac matter is a hypothetical field which is rather unexplored to date. An [[anyon]] is a type of quasiparticle that can only occur in two-dimensional systems. Considering [[bosons]] and [[fermions]], the interchange of two particles contributes a factor of 1 or -1 to the wave function. In contrast, the operation of exchanging two identical anyons causes a global phase shift. Anyons are generally classified as ''abelian'' or ''non-abelian,'' according to whether the elementary excitations of the theory transform under an [[abelian group
column3: representation]] of the [[braid group]] or a non-abelian one.<ref>{{cite journal
column6: title=Nonabelions in the fractional quantum hall effect
column18: bibcode=1991NuPhB.360..362M }}</ref> Abelian anyons have been detected in connection to the [[fractional quantum Hall effect]]. The possible construction of anyonic Dirac matter relies on the symmetry protection of crossings of anyonic energy bands. In comparison to bosons and fermions the situation gets more complicated as translations in space do not necessarily commute. Additionally, for given spatial symmetries, the group structure describing the anyon strongly depends on the specific phase of the anyon interchange. For example, for bosons, a rotation of a particle about 2{{pi}} i.e., 360<math>^\\circ</math>, will not change its wave function. For fermions, a rotation of a particle about 2{{pi}}, will contribute a factor of <math>-1</math> to its wave function, whereas a 4{{pi}} rotation, i.e., a rotation about 720<math>^\\circ</math>, will give the same wave function as before. For anyons, an even higher degree of rotation can be necessary, e.g., 6{{pi}}, 8{{pi}}, etc., to leave the wave function invariant.

column9: journal=Book Chapter in “Topological Insulators” edited by F. Ortmann,  S. Roche and S. O. Valenzuela (John Wiley & Sons)

column1: The term '''Dirac matter''' refers to a class of [[condensed matter]] systems which can be effectively described by the [[Dirac equation]]. Even though the [[Dirac equation]] itself was formulated for [[fermions]], the quasi-particles present within Dirac matter can be of any statistics. As a consequence, Dirac matter can be distinguished in [[fermionic]], [[bosonic]] or [[anyon]]ic Dirac matter. Prominent examples of Dirac matter are [[Graphene]], [[topological insulators]], Dirac semimetals, [[Weyl semimetal]]s, various [[high-temperature superconductors]] with <math>d</math>-wave pairing and [[Helium-3
column2: liquid Helium-3]]. The effective theory of such systems is classified by a specific choice of the [[Dirac mass]], the Dirac velocity, the [[Dirac matrices]] and the [[space-time curvature]]. The universal treatment of the class of Dirac matter in terms of an effective theory leads to a common features with respect to the [[density of states]], the [[heat capacity]] and impurity scattering.

column1: Members of the class of Dirac matter differ significantly in nature. However, all examples of Dirac matter are unified by similarities within the algebraic structure of an effective theory describing them.
The general definition of Dirac matter is a condensed matter system where the [[quasi-particle]] excitations can be described in curved spacetime by the generalised Dirac equation:

In the above definition <math>d_\\mu</math> denotes a [[covariant vector]] depending on the <math>(d+1)</math>-dimensional momentum <math>p</math> (<math>d</math> space <math>+ 1</math> time dimension), <math>e_a^\\mu</math> is the [[vierbein]] describing the curvature of the space, <math>m</math> the [[quasi-particle]] mass and <math>v_D</math> the Dirac velocity. Note that since in Dirac matter the Dirac equation gives the effective theory of the quasiparticles, the energy from the mass term is <math>m v_D^2</math>, not the rest mass <math>m c^2</math> of a massive particle. <math>\\gamma^\\mu</math> refers to a set of [[Dirac matrices]], where the defining for the construction is given by the anticommutation relation,
<math>\\eta^{\\mu\\nu}</math> is the [[Minkowski metric]] with signature (+ - - -) and <math>I_d</math> is the <math>d\\times d</math>-dimensional unit matrix.

In all equations, implicit summation over <math>a</math> and <math>\\mu</math> is used ([[Einstein convention]]). Furthermore, <math>\\Psi</math> is the [[wavefunction]]. The unifying feature of all Dirac matter is the matrix structure of the equation describing the quasi-particle excitations.

In the limit where <math>d_\\mu(p) = D_\\mu</math>, i.e. the [[covariant derivative]], conventional Dirac matter is obtained. However, this general definition allows the description of matter with higher order dispersion relations and in curved spacetime as long as the effective [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)
column3: matrix]] structure specific to the [[Dirac equation]].

column1: The majority of experimental realisations of Dirac matter to date are in the limit of <math>d_\\mu (p) = D_\\mu</math> which therefore defines conventional Dirac matter in which the quasiparticles are described by the [[Dirac equation in curved spacetime

Here, <math>D_\\mu</math> denotes the [[covariant derivative]]. As an example, for the flat metric, the energy of a free Dirac particle differs significantly from the classical kinetic energy where energy is proportional to momentum squared:

The Dirac velocity <math>v_D</math> gives the gradient of the <math>E-k</math> dispersion at large momenta <math>k</math>, <math>m</math> is the mass of particle or object. In the case of massless Dirac matter, such as the fermionic quasiparticles in [[graphene]] or [[Weyl semimetal]]s, the energy-momentum relation is linear,

Therefore, conventional Dirac matter includes all systems that have a linear crossing or linear behavior in some region of the energy-momentum relation. They are characterised by features that resemble an 'X', sometimes tilted or skewed and sometimes with a gap between the upper <math>\\vee</math> and lower <math>\\wedge</math> parts (the turning points of which become rounded if the origin of the gap is a mass term).
The general features and some specific examples of conventional Dirac matter are discussed in the following sections.
=== Technological relevance and tuning of Dirac matter ===

column3: Tuning of Dirac matter: As the density of states is well defined, the density of states at the Fermi level (for fermionic Dirac matter) can be nicely tuned by shifting the chemical potential <math>\\mu</math>. Additionally, introducing a mass term <math>m</math> leads to a gap between the two cones and the dispersion becomes quadratic near <math>k=0</math>.]]

column1: Dirac matter, especially fermionic Dirac matter has much potential for technological applications. For example, 2010's [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] was awarded to [[Andre Geim]] and [[Konstantin Novoselov]] \"for groundbreaking experiments regarding the material graphene\". Within the official press release of the [[Swedish Royal Academy of Science]] it is stated that<ref name=\"nobelprize\">[https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/2010/press.pdf The Nobel Prize in Physics 2010]</ref>

[...] a vast variety of practical applications now appear possible including the creation of new materials and the manufacture of innovative electronics. Graphene transistors are predicted to be substantially faster than today’s silicon transistors and result in more efficient computers.
In general, the properties of massless fermionic Dirac matter can be controlled by shifting the [[chemical potential]] by means of [[doping (semiconductor)
column3: field effect]] setup. By tuning the [[chemical potential]], it is possible to have a precise control of the number of states present, since the [[density of states]] varies in a well-defined way with energy.

column1: Additionally, depending on the specific realization of the Dirac material, it may be possible to introduce a mass term <math>m</math> that opens a gap in the spectrum - a [[band gap]]. In general, the mass term is the result of breaking a specific symmetry of the system. The size of the [[band gap]] can be controlled precisely by controlling the strength of the mass term.
The [[density of states]] of <math>d</math>-dimensional Dirac matter near the Dirac point scales as <math>N(\\epsilon)\\propto
column3: ^{d-1}</math> where <math>\\epsilon</math> is the particle energy.<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\">{{cite journal
column17: arxiv=1405.5774}}</ref> The vanishing density of states for quasiparticles in Dirac matter mimics [[semimetal]] physics for physical dimension <math>d>1</math>. In the two-dimensional systems such as graphene and topological insulators, the density of states gives a V shape, compared with the constant value for massive particles with dispersion <math>E=k^2/2m</math>.

column1: Experimental measurement of the density of states near the Dirac point by standard techniques such as scanning tunnelling microscopy often differ from the theoretical form due to the effects of disorder and interactions.<ref name=\"principi2011tunneling\">{{cite journal
column3: title=The tunneling density-of-states of interacting massless Dirac fermions

column1: Specific heat, the [[heat capacity]] per unit mass, describes the energy required to change the temperature of a sample. The low-temperature electronic [[specific heat]] of Dirac matter is <math>C(T\\to 0)\\sim T^d</math> which is different from <math>C(T\\to 0)\\sim T</math> encountered for normal metals.<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\"/> Therefore, for systems whose physical dimension is greater than 1, the specific heat can provide a clear signature of the underlying Dirac nature of the quasiparticles.

[[Landau quantization]] refers to the quantization of the cyclotron orbits of charged particles in magnetic fields. As a result, the charged particles can only occupy orbits with discrete energy values, called Landau levels. For 2-dimensional systems with a perpendicular magnetic field, the energy for Landau-levels for ordinary matter described the Schrödinger equation and Dirac matter are given by<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\"/>

Here, <math>\\omega_c</math> is the [[cyclotron frequency]] which is linearly dependent of the applied magnetic field and the charge of the particle. There are two distinct features between the Landau level quantization for 2D Schrödinger fermions (ordinary matter) and 2D Dirac fermions. First, the energy for Schrödinger fermions is linearly dependent with respect to the integer quantum number <math>n</math>, whereas it exhibits a square-root dependence for the Dirac fermions. This key difference plays an important role in the experimental verification of Dirac matter.<ref name=\"novoselov2005two\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Two-dimensional gas of massless Dirac fermions in graphene
column30: title=Observation of Landau levels of Dirac fermions in graphite
column41: bibcode=2007NatPh...3..623L}}</ref> Furthermore, for <math>n=0</math> there exists a 0 energy level for Dirac fermions which is independent of the cyclotron frequency <math>\\omega_c</math> and with that of the applied magnetic field. For example, the existence of the zeroth Landau level gives rise to a [[quantum Hall effect]] where the Hall conductance in quantized at half-integer values.<ref name=\"chen2008charged\">{{cite journal

column1: In the context of Fermionic quasiparticles, the Dirac velocity is identical to the Fermi velocity; in bosonic systems, no Fermi velocity exists, so the Dirac velocity is a more general property of such systems.
[[Graphene]] is a 2-dimensional crystalline [[allotrope]] of [[carbon]], where the carbon atoms are arranged on a [[hexagonal lattice]].

Each carbon atom forms <math>\\sigma</math>-bonds to the three neighboring atoms that lie in the graphene plane at angles of 120<math>^\\circ</math>. These bonds are mediated by three of carbon's four [[electrons]] while the fourth electron, which occupies a <math>\\mathrm{p}_z</math> [[Atomic orbital
column3: {{pi}}-bond]] that leads to the [[Electronic band structure
column4: electronic bands]] at the [[Fermi level]]. The unique transport properties and the [[semimetal]]lic state of graphene are the result of the delocalized electrons occupying these p<math>_z</math> orbitals.<ref name=\"abergel2010properties\">{{cite journal
column6: title=Properties of graphene: A theoretical perspective

column1: The semimetallic state corresponds to a linear crossing of energy bands at the <math>K</math> and <math>K'</math> points of graphene's hexagonal [[Brillouin zone]]. At these two points, the electronic structure can be effectively described by the [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)
Here, <math>\\sigma_x</math> and <math>\\sigma_y</math> are two of the three [[Pauli matrices]].

The factor <math>\\tau=+/-</math> indicates whether the Hamiltonian describes is centred on the <math>K</math> or <math>K'</math> valley at the corner of hexagonal [[Brillouin zone]]. For graphene, the Dirac velocity is about <math>\\hbar v_D \\approx 5.8</math> eV <math>\\AA</math>.<ref name=\"abergel2010properties\"/> An energy gap in the dispersion of graphene can be obtained from a low-energy Hamiltionain of the form
which now contains a mass term <math>M</math>. There are several distinct ways of introducing a mass term, and the results have different characteristics.<ref name=\"haldane\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Model for a Quantum Hall Effect without Landau Levels: Condensed-Matter Realization of the \"Parity Anomaly\"
column16: title=Quantum Spin Hall Effect in Graphene
column27: bibcode=2005PhRvL..95v6801K}}</ref> The most practical approach for creating a gap (introducing a mass term) is to break the sublattice symmetry of the lattice where each carbon atom is slightly different to its nearest but identical to its next-nearest neighbours; an effect that may result from substrate effects.

column1: A [[topological insulator]] is a material that behaves as an insulator in its interior (bulk) but whose surface contains conducting states. This property represents a non-trivial, symmetry protected [[topological order]]. As a consequence, electrons in topological insulators can only move along the [[Interface (matter)
column2: surface]] of the material. In the bulk of a non-interacting topological insulator, the [[Fermi level]] is positioned within the gap between the [[valence and conduction bands
column3: conduction and valence bands]]. On the surface, there are special states within the bulk [[energy gap]] which can be effectively described by a Dirac Hamiltonian:

column1: where <math>\\hat{\\mathbf{z}}</math> is normal to the surface and <math>{\\mathbf{\\sigma}}</math> is in the real [[spin (physics)
column2: spin]] basis. However, if we rotate spin by a [[unitary operator]], <math>U={\\rm diag}[1,i]</math>, we will end up with the standard notation of Dirac Hamiltonian, <math>{\\cal H} = \\hbar v_{D} {\\mathbf{\\sigma}}\\cdot {\\mathbf{k}}</math>.

column1: Such Dirac cones emerging on the surface of 3-dimensional crystals were observed in experiment, e.g.: [[bismuth selenide]] (Bi<math>_2</math>Se<math>_3</math>),<ref name=\"xia2009observation\">{{cite journal
column3: title=Observation of a large-gap topological-insulator class with a single Dirac cone on the surface
column34: title=Experimental realization of a topological crystalline insulator in Sn ''Te''

column3: While they are gapped, near the <math>K</math> and <math>K^\\prime</math> points of their hexagonal Brilliouin zone, the dispersions of transition metal dichalcogenides can be described by a massive Dirac equation with additional spin-orbit coupling terms that lead to spin-splitting in the valence band.]]

column1: The low-energy properties some semiconducting [[transition metal dichalcogenide monolayers]],
can be described by a two-dimensional massive (gapped) Dirac Hamiltonian with an additional term describing a strong [[spin–orbit coupling]]:<ref name=\"Xiao12\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Coupled Spin and Valley Physics in Monolayers ofMoS2and Other Group-VI Dichalcogenides
column23: title=Effective lattice Hamiltonian for monolayer MoS2: Tailoring electronic structure with perpendicular electric and magnetic fields
column38: title=Monolayer MoS2: Trigonal warping, theΓvalley, and spin-orbit coupling effects
column59: title=Three-band tight-binding model for monolayers of group-VIB transition metal dichalcogenides

column1: The spin-orbit coupling <math>\\lambda</math> provides a large spin-splitting in the valence band and <math>s</math> indicates the [[spin (physics)
column2: spin]] degree of freedom. As for graphene, <math>\\tau</math> gives the valley degree of freedom - whether near the <math>K</math> or <math>K^\\prime</math> point of the hexagonal Brillouin zone. Transition metal dichalcogenide monolayers are often discussed in reference to potential applications in [[valleytronics]].

column1: [[Weyl semimetal]]s, for example tantalum arsenide (TaAs),<ref name=Huang>{{cite journal
column30: title=A Weyl Fermion semimetal with surface Fermi arcs in the transition metal monopnictide TaAs class
column40: title=Weyl Semimetal Phase in Noncentrosymmetric Transition-Metal Monophosphides
column100: title=Discovery of a Weyl Fermion semimetal and topological Fermi arcs
column112: title=Observation of the Chiral-Anomaly-Induced Negative Magnetoresistance in 3D Weyl Semimetal Ta ''As''
column147: title=New type of Weyl semimetal with quadratic double Weyl fermions
column148: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column188: bibcode=2016PNAS..113.1180H}}</ref> have a Hamiltonian that is very similar to that of graphene, but now includes all three Pauli matrices and the linear crossings occur in 3D:

column1: Since all three [[Pauli matrices]] are present, there is no further Pauli matrix that could open a gap in the spectrum and Weyl points are therefore [[topologically protected]].<ref name=\"wehling2014dirac\"/> Tilting of the linear cones so the Dirac velocity varies leads to type II Weyl semimetals.<ref name=\"soluyanov2015type\">{{cite journal
One distinct, experimentally observable feature of Weyl semimetals is that the surface states form [[Fermi arc]]s since the [[Fermi surface]] does not form a closed loop.
In crystals that are symmetric under [[point reflection
column3: time reversal]], electronic energy bands are two-fold degenerate. This degeneracy is referred to as [[Kramers degeneracy]]. Therefore, semimetals with linear crossings of two energy bands (two-fold degeneracy) at the [[Fermi energy]] exhibit a four-fold degeneracy at the crossing point. The effective [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)
column4: Hamiltonian]] for these states can be written as

column1: This has exactly the matrix structure of Dirac matter. Examples of experimentally realised Dirac semimetals are [[Bismuth#Bismuthine and bismuthides
column4: title=Dirac semimetal and topological phase transitions inA3Bi (A=Na, K, Rb)
column30: title=Discovery of a Three-Dimensional Topological Dirac Semimetal, Na3Bi
column62: title=Observation of Fermi arc surface states in a topological metal
column106: title=Three-dimensional Dirac semimetal and quantum transport in Cd3As2

column1: [[File:Dispersions for bosonic (left) and fermionic (right) Dirac materials.png
column3: Dispersions for bosonic (left) and fermionic (right) Dirac materials. In contrast to the fermionic case where Pauli exclusion confines excitations close to the Fermi energy, the description of boson requires the entire Brillioun zone.]]

column1: While historic interest focussed on fermionic quasiparticles that have potential for technological applications, particularly in electronics, the mathematical structure of the [[Dirac equation]] is not restricted to the [[Particle statistics
column2: statistics of the particles]]. This has led to recent development of the concept of bosonic Dirac matter.

column1: In the case of [[bosons]], there is no [[Pauli exclusion principle]] to confine excitations close to the [[chemical potential]] (Fermi energy for fermions) so the entire [[Brillouin zone]] must be included. At low temperatures, the bosons will collect at the lowest energy point, the <math>\\Gamma</math>-point of the lower band. Energy must be added to excite the quasiparticles to the vicinity of the linear crossing point.

Several examples of Dirac matter with fermionic quasi-particles occur in systems where there is a hexagonal crystal lattice; so bosonic quasiparticles on an hexagonal lattice are the natural candidates for bosonic Dirac matter. In fact, the underlying symmetry of a crystal structure strongly constrains and protects the emergence of linear band crossings. Typical bosonic [[quasiparticles]] in [[condensed matter]] are [[magnon]]s, [[phonons]], [[polaritons]] and [[plasmons]].

Existing examples of bosonic Dirac matter include transition metal [[halides]] such as CrX<math>_3</math> (X= Cl, Br, I), where the [[magnon]] spectrum exhibits linear crossings,<ref name=\"pershoguba2018dirac\">{{cite journal
column24: bibcode=2018PhRvX...8a1010P}}</ref> granular [[superconductors]] in a [[honeycomb lattice]] <ref name=\"Banerjee\">{{cite journal
column26: title=Granular superconductor in a honeycomb lattice as a realization of bosonic Dirac material
column43: bibcode=2016PhRvB..93m4502B}}</ref> and hexagonal arrays of [[semiconductor microcavities]] hosting [[microcavity polaritons]] with linear crossings.<ref name=\"jacqmin2014direct\">{{cite journal
column46: title=Direct Observation of Dirac Cones and a Flatband in a Honeycomb Lattice for Polaritons
column73: bibcode=2014PhRvL.112k6402J}}</ref> Like graphene, all these systems have an hexagonal lattice structure.

column1: Anyonic Dirac matter is a hypothetical field which is rather unexplored to date. An [[anyon]] is a type of quasiparticle that can only occur in two-dimensional systems. Considering [[bosons]] and [[fermions]], the interchange of two particles contributes a factor of 1 or -1 to the wave function. In contrast, the operation of exchanging two identical anyons causes a global phase shift. Anyons are generally classified as ''abelian'' or ''non-abelian,'' according to whether the elementary excitations of the theory transform under an [[abelian group
column3: representation]] of the [[braid group]] or a non-abelian one.<ref>{{cite journal
column6: title=Nonabelions in the fractional quantum hall effect
column18: bibcode=1991NuPhB.360..362M }}</ref> Abelian anyons have been detected in connection to the [[fractional quantum Hall effect]]. The possible construction of anyonic Dirac matter relies on the symmetry protection of crossings of anyonic energy bands. In comparison to bosons and fermions the situation gets more complicated as translations in space do not necessarily commute. Additionally, for given spatial symmetries, the group structure describing the anyon strongly depends on the specific phase of the anyon interchange. For example, for bosons, a rotation of a particle about 2{{pi}} i.e., 360<math>^\\circ</math>, will not change its wave function. For fermions, a rotation of a particle about 2{{pi}}, will contribute a factor of <math>-1</math> to its wave function, whereas a 4{{pi}} rotation, i.e., a rotation about 720<math>^\\circ</math>, will give the same wave function as before. For anyons, an even higher degree of rotation can be necessary, e.g., 6{{pi}}, 8{{pi}}, etc., to leave the wave function invariant.

column1: '''Mary-Belle Kirschner''' (born 23 October 1999), better known by her online alias '''Belle Delphine''', is an English [[Internet personality]], model, and [[YouTuber]]. She is most notable for her [[glamour photography
column3: modeling]] on [[Instagram]]. Her posts on the platform featured a risqué and self-proclaimed \"weird\" aesthetic, and were often influenced by popular [[Internet memes]] and trends. As a result of her online activity, she became an Internet meme in her own right.

column1: In the summer of 2019, Kirschner registered a joke [[Pornhub]] account and began selling her \"GamerGirl Bath Water\" product through her online store, garnering her a great amount of media coverage online. Shortly after, her Instagram account was deleted due to community guideline violations. Media outlets have described Kirschner as a cross between an [[Internet troll]] and a performance artist, as well as an [[e-girls and e-boys
column2: e-girl]]. Kirschner has also been cited as an influence on the e-girl aesthetic commonly adopted by [[TikTok]] users.

column1: On 1 July 2019, Kirschner launched her online storefront, along with a product that was dubbed \"GamerGirl Bath Water\".<ref name=Hernandez2019/><ref name=Dodgson2019b>{{cite web
column5: title=An Instagram star put her own bathwater up for sale for $30 a bottle, and it sold out in 3 days
column9: accessdate=21 July 2019}}</ref> The product was marketed as the remains of her bath water and was priced at $30 (£24).<ref name=Hernandez2019/> Kirschner stated that the idea to sell her bath water came from continued fan comments on her photos saying they would drink her bathwater.<ref name=Aggeler2019/> Upon initially selling the product, Kirschner added the note: \"This water is not for drinking and should only be used for sentimental purposes.\"<ref name=Hernandez2019/> The product was a commercial success for Kirschner, as the first run of the bath water sold out in three days.<ref name=Dodgson2019b/>

column1: Her selling of GamerGirl Bath Water was met with considerable controversy, media coverage, and [[Internet memes]].<ref name=Dodgson2019b/><ref name=Vivar2019>{{cite web
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> The response from general Internet users also included tangential hoaxes based around the bath water, as well as parody and knock-off products. Two days after the bath water product sold out, a website was created attempting to capitalize on its success, selling \"GamerGirl Pee\" for just under $10,000; this new website and product was confirmed to not be associated with Kirschner.<ref name=Sung2019>{{cite web
column15: title=Belle Delphine, who sold gamer girl bathwater, isn't promoting that gamer girl pee
column21: url-status=live}}</ref> @BakeRises, a since-banned Twitter user, impersonated ''[[The Daily Mail]]'' as a means to fabricate a headline alleging that Kirschner's product caused a [[herpes]] outbreak.<ref name=Rivera2019>{{cite web
column25: title=The 'Gamer Girl Bath Water' Saga Keeps Getting Stranger
column31: url-status=live}}</ref> [[Snopes]] debunked this claim, stating that \"the 'herpes' twist to the story was no more than a hoax.\"<ref name=MacGuill2019>{{cite web
column35: title=Did People Contract Herpes After Drinking Instagram Star Belle Delphine's Bathwater?
column38: accessdate=29 July 2019}}</ref> YouTube video responses also sprung up featuring individuals drinking, cooking, and vaping the bath water.<ref name=Dickson2019/><ref name=Vivar2019/>

column1: EJ Dickson of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' noted that the response from media outlets alternated between \"deriding [Kirschner's] fans for their naïvete and applauding her for her marketing savvy.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/> Katie Bishop, writing for ''[[The Guardian]]'', reported that the sale was \"widely mocked.\"<ref name=Bishop2019/> In concurrence, the ''[[International Business Times]]'' wrote, \"while some people were amused by the idea of buying someone's bathwater, others have said that anyone who bought the GamerGirl Bath Water was 'sad' and 'pathetic.'\"<ref name=Vivar2019/> Patricia Hernandez of ''[[Polygon (website)
column2: Polygon]]'' commented, \"Perhaps this seems like a strange thing to do, but it's very similar to the phenomenon of sex workers selling intimate items, such as panties.\" Hernandez additionally opined, \"What's curious about [Kirschner's] side hustle here is that it seems to be a mixture of business and next-level performance art. In the video advertising the bath water, she outright calls this a stunt. And if you look at her wider Instagram oeuvre, [Kirschner's] work is defined by her willingness to ''go there''. The result is as strange as it is funny.\"<ref name=Hernandez2019/>

column1: In a July 2019 interview with ''The Guardian'', Kirschner stated, \"I'm lucky. I can do crazy things and get to see the world react to it, and there's definitely enjoyment in that, even if it's sometimes a little scary. I get a bigger reaction to my weirder content but I think that's only possible because I also make risqué content.\"<ref name=Bishop2019>{{cite web
column5: title=Who is paying $30 for 'gamer girl' Belle Delphine's bath water?
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> She added, \"I think it's been amazing and fun, but it's time to move on to new things. I have a diary next to my bed full of crazy ideas. I'm not sure what will top this, but I'm looking forward to seeing what will come next.\"<ref name=Bishop2019/>

column1: ===Instagram account ban and social media hiatus===
On 19 July 2019, Kirschner's Instagram account was banned from the platform.<ref name=Molina2019>{{cite web
column5: title=Belle Delphine, Internet star who sold her bath water, has Instagram account deleted
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> ''Business Insider'' reported that Kirschner's account ban came \"after a seemingly co-ordinated reporting campaign against her.\"<ref name=Kanter2019>{{cite web
column15: title=The Instagram star who went viral for selling her bathwater has had her account shut down after people reported her
column21: url-status=live}}</ref> However, a spokesperson for Instagram told the outlet that her account was not removed due to the aforementioned campaign, but rather because it violated the company's community guidelines.<ref name=Kanter2019/> The specific post or reason that led to Kirschner's ban was not provided by the spokesperson, who cited privacy.<ref name=Maxim2019>{{cite web
column24: title=Instagram Model Who Sold Her Bathwater to 'Thirsty Gamer Boys' Has Account Shut Down For Rules Violation
column31: url-status=live}}</ref> At the time of her ban, the \"belle.delphine\" account accumulated over 4.5 million followers, according to ''Business Insider'' and [[Social Blade]], a social media analytics firm.<ref name=Kanter2019/><ref name=SocialBlade>{{cite web

column1: Commenting on the ban, she stated she was in contact with Instagram to restore her account.<ref name=Soen2019/> After her ban from Instagram, Kirschner utilized her Patreon and [[Twitter]] accounts to communicate with her followers. After a tweet on 21 August, she became uncharacteristically quiet on her social media platforms.<ref name=Co2019>{{cite web
column5: title=Belle Delphine tweets 'arrest mugshot' in response to conspiracy theories
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> This prompted many of her Patreon supporters to believe they were being scammed, as she previously promised upcoming special content.<ref name=Co2019/><ref name=Bryan2019>{{cite web
column15: title=Belle Delphine now claims she was arrested after vandalizing a car
column21: url-status=live}}</ref> During her hiatus, [[PewDiePie]] featured memes relating to her GamerGirl Bath Water product on his ''Meme Review'' series.<ref name=Leskin2019-a/>

column2: H3 Podcast]]'' co-host Ethan Klein suggested that Kirschner may have had legal trouble due to posting her bath water product.<ref name=Co2019/> Days later, on 7 October, Kirschner tweeted an image claiming it to be her mugshot, with a caption detailing she was arrested.<ref name=Co2019/> The image contained a \"[[Metropolitan Police Service]]\" watermark, although there was not any external proof of an arrest, and the Metropolitan Police said the claim could not be verified.<ref name=Soen2019>{{cite web
column6: title=Who is Belle Delphine? The British YouTuber claiming she's been arrested
column9: accessdate=29 March 2020}}</ref><ref name=Co2019/> Kirschner later followed up the tweet, detailing that someone stole her pet hamster at a party and that her vandalization of that person's car resulted in her arrest.<ref name=Bryan2019/><ref name=Song2019>{{cite web
column13: title=Gamer Girl Belle Delphine Says She Was Arrested
column20: url-status=live}}</ref> Online publications and users raised concerns over the validity of Kirschner's claims due to her previous trolling; in addition, some noted that Metropolitan Police mugshots do not contain watermarks.<ref name=Bryan2019/>

column1: Kirschner's Belle Delphine persona and her related content has garnered much curiosity and scrutiny from online users and media outlets alike. Various outlets, including ''[[New York (magazine)
column3: Polygon]]'' have described her as a \"troll\", and several instances of her activity online as \"stunts\".<ref name=Aggeler2019/><ref name=Leskin2019-a/><ref name=Hernandez2019/><ref name=Rivera2019/> Many of those outlets also assert that there is a satirical and ironic layer to her content; Bishop wrote that Kirschner \"has successfully tapped into an online subculture by creating content that exists somewhere between Internet pranks and erotic modeling. For many of her followers, Delphine is a personality before she is a pornographic model.\"<ref name=Bishop2019/> Kirschner's polarizing social media presence has also been noted, with ''[[Evening Standard
column4: London Evening Standard]]'' writing that she \"has sparked a flurry of debate online, with fans branding her everything from a master manipulator to a harmful sexist stereotype of gamer girls.\"<ref name=Hills2019>{{cite web
column8: title=Who is Belle Delphine? From selling her bath water to being 'arrested' over a hamster theft, here's what to know about the Internet personality
column14: url-status=live}}</ref> ''[[Business Insider]]'' cited one fan response in particular, which likened Kirschner to a \"2019 [[Andy Warhol]]\".<ref name=Leskin2019-a/> Alex Galbraith, writing for ''[[Complex (magazine)
column15: Complex]]'', commented that her \"exceptionally weird\" stunts \"seem to be satirizing the whole idea of sexiness.\"<ref name=Galbraith2019/> Citing her as \"a surrealist troll that became too much for Instagram,\" ''Business Insider'' ranked Kirschner 89th on the 2019 edition of its UK Tech 100 list.<ref name=HanburyHamiltonWood2019>{{cite web
column23: title=UK Tech 100: The 100 most influential people shaping British technology in 2019
column29: url-status=live}}</ref> The list's purpose is to feature the one-hundred \"most interesting, innovative, and influential people shaping the [[Science and technology in the United Kingdom

column1: Her association with a [[gamer girl]] image has been particularly emphasized by media publications. ''Kotaku'' has described her as a \"peak self-aware [[e-girls and e-boys
column6: title=Young Women Are Reclaiming The Slur 'Egirl'
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> ''Business Insider'' also referenced Delphine as a figure that some may point to as \"a symbol of the first wave of e-girl,\"<ref name=Leskin2019-b>{{cite web

column1: Everything you need to know about e-girls and e-boys, teen gamers who have emerged as the antithesis of Instagram influencers
A glimpse into the subculture of e-girls and e-boys, the teen gamers who are the radical antithesis of the Instagram influencer [2 October 2019 archive]
column5: archive-date=2 October 2019}}</ref> and Delphine has been cited by several media outlets as helping influence the e-girl aesthetic commonly found on [[TikTok]].<ref name=Leskin2019-b/><ref name=Grayson2020>{{cite web
column9: title=Down the Rabbit Hole of Twitch Streamers' TikToks
column13: accessdate=23 March 2020}}</ref> ''Rolling Stones''{{'}}s EJ Dickson described Kirschner's posts as being more \"bizarre\" and \"ridiculous\", rather than \"overtly sexual\", and opined that: \"Such content appears to indicate that Delphine is leaning into — if not overtly parodying — the perception of the ideal girl as a hot, innocent young thing whose desire to play ''[[Fortnite]]'' is only eclipsed by her desire for nerdy gamer boy dick.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/> After her GamerGirl Bath Water product went viral on the Internet, ''[[Kotaku]]'' opined that:

column1: It is not a huge stretch to assert that [Kirschner], who has built up a body of work that can be read as satirical, might be in the midst of some sort of long-term joke here, especially given her long list of stunts that all tend to subvert or toy with well-established fetish tropes. Even the notion of 'gamer girl bath water' plays with all manner of stereotypes about women in games and how some men see them: as mythical unicorns to lust after.

column2: The Telegraph]]'', opined that \"for women to truly escape gaming's gendered grip, we need to raise more non-fetishized Gamer Girls to the top. [Kirschner] is proof there is still quite a way to go.\"<ref name=London2019>{{cite web
column6: title=Is Belle Delphine proof gaming culture can't escape its hyper-sexualised past?
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> Aoife Wilson, Head of Video at ''[[Eurogamer]]'' has conversely commented positively on Kirschner's online persona and content, asserting that \"[Kirschner] is an incredibly savvy businesswoman. She gained a huge online following through her love of cosplay and her ability to replicate real-life ''ahegao'' faces. She's kept that momentum going by engaging with her followers and trying new things, always skirting the line between sexy and surreal. She absolutely knows her audience.\"<ref name=London2019/>

column1: Her content's connection with themes found in Japanese culture and media has also been examined. Dickson wrote that the references to Japanese culture in Kirschner's content have garnered her some criticism, as she has been \"accused of racism and [[cultural appropriation]] in her cosplay, as well as capitalizing on the eroticization of young girls.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/> Conversely, Japanese adult performer [[Marica Hase]] opined \"I see her manga characters as more of an homage and not racist.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/>
On why Kirschner attracts much controversy, Dickson wrote that:

Delphine markets herself as a 'gamer girl', which engages with a very specific stereotype about women in gaming. In the gaming community, there's a longstanding perception of female gamers as desperate attention-seekers who sexualize themselves to get more views and capitalize on horny dudes' desire for nerdy female counterparts.

column1: '''Mary-Belle Kirschner''' (born 23 October 1999), better known by her online alias '''Belle Delphine''', is an English [[Internet personality]], model, and [[YouTuber]]. She is most notable for her [[glamour photography
column3: modeling]] on [[Instagram]]. Her posts on the platform featured a risqué and self-proclaimed \"weird\" aesthetic, and were often influenced by popular [[Internet memes]] and trends. As a result of her online activity, she became an Internet meme in her own right.

column1: In the summer of 2019, Kirschner registered a joke [[Pornhub]] account and began selling her \"GamerGirl Bath Water\" product through her online store, garnering her a great amount of media coverage online. Shortly after, her Instagram account was deleted due to community guideline violations. Media outlets have described Kirschner as a cross between an [[Internet troll]] and a performance artist, as well as an [[e-girls and e-boys
column2: e-girl]]. Kirschner has also been cited as an influence on the e-girl aesthetic commonly adopted by [[TikTok]] users.

column1: Kirschner was born on 23 October 1999 in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]], and eventually moved to the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name=Sloan2019>{{cite web
column5: title=Belle Delphine: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know
column14: title=Belle Delphine: 12 Facts You (Probably) Didn't Know About The Online Star

column36: url-status=live}}</ref> Kirschner has had an Instagram account since 2015,<ref name=Leskin2019-a>{{cite web

column5: title=Meet Belle Delphine, the Instagram star who sold her bathwater to 'thirsty gamer boys' and had her account shut down over a rules violation [19 July 2019 archive]
column9: archive-date=19 July 2019}}</ref> and in July 2016, she registered a [[YouTube]] account.<ref>{{cite web
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> In August 2016, Kirschner uploaded a [[Beauty YouTuber
column18: makeup tutorial video]], demonstrating how to do a [[eye shadow
column32: title=Is Belle Delphine, a.k.a. Bathwater Gamer Girl, the Greatest Troll On the Internet?

column1: In 2018, Kirschner began to regularly upload pictures of her modeling and cosplaying.<ref name=Aggeler2019/> Her Instagram modeling had a distinct, self-proclaimed \"weird elf kitty girl\" aesthetic, and she used accessories such as pink wigs, [[hold-ups
column2: thigh-high stockings]], and cat ears.<ref name=Aggeler2019/> In March 2018, Kirschner launched a [[Patreon]] account, where supporters could pledge a monthly donation.<ref name=Dickson2019/> Her content has earned her over 4,400 supporters on the website.<ref name=Leskin2019-a/> ''[[Polygon (website)
column3: Polygon]]'' noted that one follower spent $2,500 in exchange for a personal [[Skype]] conversation with Kirschner.<ref name=Hernandez2019>{{cite web
column7: title=The woman selling that 'GamerGirl Bath Water' loves to troll her viewers

column1: In September 2018, she uploaded a second YouTube video featuring her giving a tour of her pastel pink room, while wearing fake braces and thigh-high stockings.<ref name=Dickson2019/> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' noted that her aesthetic in this second video is more in-line with that of the one she later adopted during her rise to prominence on Instagram; the publication described that aesthetic as \"alien Disney princess porn star.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/> Once she adopted this new online aesthetic, her Instagram account surged from 850,000 followers in November 2018 to 4.2 million in July 2019.<ref name=Dickson2019/> Her content also began to notably and frequently include ''[[ahegao]]'' facial expressions, which are exaggerated, eyes-rolled-back expressions that signify an orgasm and often featured in [[hentai
column2: adult anime]].<ref name=Aggeler2019/><ref name=Galbraith2019/><ref name=Cole2020>{{cite web
column6: title=How Censorship Created Porn's New Face of Pleasure
column10: accessdate=7 March 2020}}</ref> Kirschner additionally produces [[cosplay]] content, as she has cosplayed characters such as [[Harley Quinn]] and [[D.Va]].<ref name=Dickson2019/> ''[[Complex (magazine)
column11: Complex]]'' further described the nature of Kirschner's content, detailing that \"along with her more traditional photos, she has posted clips of herself coyly eating a raw egg, shell and all. A scroll through her feed is just as likely to find colorful thirst traps as it is to see photos of her playing with a dead octopus.\"<ref name=Galbraith2019>{{cite web
column15: title=Instagram Model Sells Her Bathwater to Thirsty Fans

column1: ===Pornhub account and GamerGirl Bath Water stunts===
In June 2019, Kirschner posted on Instagram, promising to create a [[Pornhub]] account if her post reached 1 million likes.<ref name=Hill2019>{{cite web
column5: title=Cosplayer Belle Delphine trolled her followers with the promise of a Pornhub account
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> Pornhub responded to the post, calling it \"the best news.\"<ref name=Prokos2019/> The post quickly earned over 1.8 million likes; in response, Kirschner held up her promise and created a Pornhub account, to which she uploaded 12 videos.<ref name=Hill2019/> Reactions to this were mixed, as many of Kirschner's fans were disappointed as her uploads were [[Internet troll
column12: troll videos]] that featured misleading titles and thumbnails.<ref name=Dickson2019/><ref name=Prokos2019>{{cite web
column16: title=Belle Delphine Fans Are Furious After Cosplayer Trolls Them With Unsexy Pornhub Videos
column22: url-status=live}}</ref> Each of the videos received poor like-to-dislike ratios, ranging between 66% and 77% dislikes.<ref name=Crichton2019>{{cite web
column26: title=Cosplay Instagram Star Belle Delphine Trolls Followers With PornHub Account
column32: url-status=live}}</ref> Harry Hill of ''[[Mashable]]'' commented that \"Arguably the best video, 'PEWDIEPIE goes all the way INSIDE Belle Delphine,' is a minute-long clip of a cat ear-clad [Kirschner] ''eating'' a picture of YouTuber [[PewDiePie]], winking throughout.\"<ref name=Hill2019/> PewDiePie responded to Kirschner's video, continuing with its joking nature.<ref name=Rivera2019/><ref name=Dodgson2019a>{{cite web
column36: title=Instagram star Belle Delphine trolled fans with meme videos on PornHub
column40: accessdate=6 December 2019}}</ref> Later in 2019, Kirschner was nominated for a [[Pornhub Awards
column45: title=PornHub nominates Instagram stars Tana Mongeau and Belle Delphine for awards although both haven't made any porn
column51: url-status=live}}</ref> In December, Pornhub released their annual statistics report, which included Kirschner as the most-searched celebrity in 2019;<ref name=Song2019b>{{cite web
column55: title=Belle Delphine Was Pornhub's Most Searched For Celebrity in 2019
column62: url-status=live}}</ref> \"Belle Delphine\" was also the fourth-most-searched term in general during the year.<ref name=Naftulin2019>{{cite web
column66: title=People wanted to watch lots of 'alien' and 'Belle Delphine' porn in 2019, PornHub data reveals

column29: url-status=live}}</ref> The list's purpose is to feature the one-hundred \"most interesting, innovative, and influential people shaping the [[Science and technology in the United Kingdom

column1: Her association with a [[gamer girl]] image has been particularly emphasized by media publications. ''Kotaku'' has described her as a \"peak self-aware [[e-girls and e-boys
column6: title=Young Women Are Reclaiming The Slur 'Egirl'
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> ''Business Insider'' also referenced Delphine as a figure that some may point to as \"a symbol of the first wave of e-girl,\"<ref name=Leskin2019-b>{{cite web

column1: Everything you need to know about e-girls and e-boys, teen gamers who have emerged as the antithesis of Instagram influencers
A glimpse into the subculture of e-girls and e-boys, the teen gamers who are the radical antithesis of the Instagram influencer [2 October 2019 archive]
column5: archive-date=2 October 2019}}</ref> and Delphine has been cited by several media outlets as helping influence the e-girl aesthetic commonly found on [[TikTok]].<ref name=Leskin2019-b/><ref name=Grayson2020>{{cite web
column9: title=Down the Rabbit Hole of Twitch Streamers' TikToks
column13: accessdate=23 March 2020}}</ref> ''Rolling Stones''{{'}}s EJ Dickson described Kirschner's posts as being more \"bizarre\" and \"ridiculous\", rather than \"overtly sexual\", and opined that: \"Such content appears to indicate that Delphine is leaning into — if not overtly parodying — the perception of the ideal girl as a hot, innocent young thing whose desire to play ''[[Fortnite]]'' is only eclipsed by her desire for nerdy gamer boy dick.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/> After her GamerGirl Bath Water product went viral on the Internet, ''[[Kotaku]]'' opined that:

column1: It is not a huge stretch to assert that [Kirschner], who has built up a body of work that can be read as satirical, might be in the midst of some sort of long-term joke here, especially given her long list of stunts that all tend to subvert or toy with well-established fetish tropes. Even the notion of 'gamer girl bath water' plays with all manner of stereotypes about women in games and how some men see them: as mythical unicorns to lust after.

column2: The Telegraph]]'', opined that \"for women to truly escape gaming's gendered grip, we need to raise more non-fetishized Gamer Girls to the top. [Kirschner] is proof there is still quite a way to go.\"<ref name=London2019>{{cite web
column6: title=Is Belle Delphine proof gaming culture can't escape its hyper-sexualised past?
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> Aoife Wilson, Head of Video at ''[[Eurogamer]]'' has conversely commented positively on Kirschner's online persona and content, asserting that \"[Kirschner] is an incredibly savvy businesswoman. She gained a huge online following through her love of cosplay and her ability to replicate real-life ''ahegao'' faces. She's kept that momentum going by engaging with her followers and trying new things, always skirting the line between sexy and surreal. She absolutely knows her audience.\"<ref name=London2019/>

column1: Her content's connection with themes found in Japanese culture and media has also been examined. Dickson wrote that the references to Japanese culture in Kirschner's content have garnered her some criticism, as she has been \"accused of racism and [[cultural appropriation]] in her cosplay, as well as capitalizing on the eroticization of young girls.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/> Conversely, Japanese adult performer [[Marica Hase]] opined \"I see her manga characters as more of an homage and not racist.\"<ref name=Dickson2019/>
On why Kirschner attracts much controversy, Dickson wrote that:

Delphine markets herself as a 'gamer girl', which engages with a very specific stereotype about women in gaming. In the gaming community, there's a longstanding perception of female gamers as desperate attention-seekers who sexualize themselves to get more views and capitalize on horny dudes' desire for nerdy female counterparts.

column5: title=If you bought influencer bathwater, could you test it for DNA?
