column3: Press Secretary to the First Lady]]
title=Eastmont graduate named new press secretary for President Trump
column9: accessdate=November 8, 2019}}</ref> ([[née]] '''Allen'''; born July 23, 1976) is an American White House official who served as the 30th [[White House press secretary]] and as [[White House Communications Director
column10: White House communications director]] from July 2019<ref name=ncwlife_20190625_FitzSimmons /><ref name=krem_20190625_Carroll /><ref name=\"Fox\">{{Cite news
column12: title=Stephanie Grisham to be the new White House Press Secretary
column22: title=Grisham out as West Wing press secretary without having held a briefing
column28: first2=Kate}}</ref> She held no press conferences as press secretary, instead opting for interviews on conservative news outlets.<ref>{{Cite web
column30: title=Grisham out as West Wing press secretary without having held a briefing
column40: title=Stephanie Grisham Departs As White House Press Secretary
column50: title=White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham has yet to hold a briefing with reporters, but finds time for Fox News
column55: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> She was a press aide to [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign
column58: title=Who Is Stephanie Grisham? She Just Replaced Sarah Sanders
column65: title=Trump Names Stephanie Grisham, Aide to First Lady, as Sarah Sanders's Successor
column72: access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> and then a member of the presidential [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump
column75: title=Stephanie Grisham is Trump's communications czar. Only most people wouldn't know it.
column83: title=This Arizonan is going to the White House to work for Donald Trump
column90: title=Trump taps Stephanie Grisham as White House spokeswoman
column95: access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> Grisham assumed the role of chief of staff to the First Lady on April 7, 2020.<ref>{{Cite news
column97: title=White House spokeswoman Grisham switches to first lady's staff

column1: Stephanie Ann Allen was born in Colorado to Dave and Elizabeth Ann Allen, the middle child of three.<ref name=ncwlife_20190625_FitzSimmons /><ref name=wapo_20190828 /> Her family are farmers.<ref name=wapo_20190828 />

She moved with her mother to [[East Wenatchee, Washington]], where she graduated from [[Eastmont High School]] in 1994.<ref name=ncwlife_20190625_FitzSimmons /><ref name=krem_20190625_Carroll>{{cite web
column3: title=New White House press secretary has ties to East Wenatchee
column9: access-date=November 8, 2019}}</ref> Her mother has since moved to Nebraska, where she is known as Ann Schroder.<ref name=azr_20190626>{{cite news
column11: title=Stephanie Grisham's unlikely path from Arizona politics to White House press secretary

column1: Grisham began voting in Arizona as a registered Democrat in 1997.<ref name=azr_20190626 />
As Stephanie Ann Sommerville, she married Danny Don Marries in Nevada on April 7, 1997.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=Heavy_20190626_McBride>{{cite web
column3: title=Is Stephanie Grisham Married? Learn About Her Ex Husband
column8: access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> They met at [[Mesa State College]] in [[Grand Junction, Colorado]].<ref name=star_20130707>{{cite web
column10: title='We've said our goodbyes:' KOLD anchor posts his pain
column15: access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> They had a son in June 1998, and her husband joined [[KOLD-TV]] as a news anchor in [[Tucson, Arizona]], on the day after their son's first birthday.<ref name=Heavy_20190626_McBride /><ref name=star_20130707 /> They divorced in 2004.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=sentinel_20190626>{{cite news
column17: title=Ex-Tucsonan Grisham named press secretary for President Trump
column26: title=The Untold Truth of Stephanie Gresham

column1: Later in 2004, she subsequently married [[Todd Grisham]], a KOLD sportscaster. They divorced in 2006.<ref name=sentinel_20190626 />
Around 2008, she had a second son.<ref name=Heavy_20190626_McBride/>
Following her divorce(s), Grisham was the spokeswoman for [[American Automobile Association
column4: title=Ex-Tucsonan named spokeswoman for first lady Melania Trump
column9: accessdate=October 17, 2018}}</ref> but was fired within a year after being accused of cheating on expense reports.<ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\">{{cite news
column12: title=Stephanie Grisham's Turbulent Ascent to a Top White House Role
column18: url-status=live }}</ref> Grisham was fired from a subsequent job at ad agency Mindspace over plagiarism charges, copying AAA material verbatim into her client's web page.<ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" />

column1: From 2008 to 2010, Grisham worked as a spokeswoman for the [[Arizona Charter Schools Association]].<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" /> There she met [[Tom Horne]], Arizona's superintendent of public schools.<ref name=azr_20190626 />

Circa 2011 to 2014, Grisham served as spokeswoman for Tom Horne after he was elected Arizona attorney general.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> She witnessed the [[execution of Joseph Wood]] and controversially claimed that the two hour ordeal had been \"quite peaceful\" despite contrary observations.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Arizona killer takes 2 hours to die, fueling lethal-injection debate - Los Angeles Times
column14: title=It's Time to End Our State-Sponsored Barbarism
column22: title=Stephanie Grisham, new White House press secretary, had controversial Arizona career

column1: In 2012, Grisham also worked for [[Mitt Romney]]'s [[Mitt Romney 2012 presidential campaign
column4: title=Single mother from the Valley working for the Trump White House

column1: After Republican [[Mark Brnovich]] defeated Horne in the 2014 GOP primary, Grisham worked as a spokesperson for the [[Arizona House of Representatives]] Republican caucus.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> She revoked the [[Arizona Capitol Times]]'s press credentials hours after their reporting that the House speaker, [[David Gowan]], had traveled at state taxpayers' expense during his campaign for Congress.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=azct_20160408_Small>{{cite web
column3: title=This new background check policy is only the latest retaliation from Gowan's House
column8: accessdate=November 16, 2019}}</ref> Reporters refused to comply, and Gowan rescinded the order.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" />

column1: In September 2015, Grisham worked as a press coordinator for [[Pope Francis's 2015 visit to North America#26 September (New York City, Philadelphia)
column2: Pope Francis's visit to Philadelphia]] as an independent contractor.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Arizona House spokeswoman prepping for the pope

column1: Circa August 2015, Grisham started working as a press aide to [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign
column2: 2016 presidential campaign]].<ref name=\"Fortune06142019\"/><ref name=\"azr_20170119\"/> She helped arrange his campaign stops in Phoenix and around the state and region throughout the primary, a role that quickly expanded to include his rallies around the U.S.<ref name=\"azr_20170119\"/> Grisham was on state payroll until May 2016, when she took an unpaid leave from the Arizona House of Representatives to work on Trump's campaign.<ref name=azct_20190625_Howard /><ref name=\"knau_20161201\">{{cite web
column4: title=Trump Names House PR Person To Staff, Treasurer As Adviser

column1: After his victory, Grisham was named a special adviser for operations and served on Trump's transition team.<ref name=\"azr_20170119\"/><ref name=\"knau_20161201\"/><ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate=October 17, 2018}}</ref> Arizona House speaker David Gowan paid her $19,000 in state salary over an 8-week period while she was serving as a member of the Trump transition team.<ref name=azct_20190625_Howard /><ref name=azct_20170425_Stephenson>{{cite web
column15: title=FLOTUS spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham on state payroll while on Trump's victory tour and transition team

column1: After Trump's January 2017 inauguration, Grisham was named deputy press secretary for [[Sean Spicer]] in the West Wing of the White House.<ref name=\"fox10phoenix\"/><ref name=\"Fortune06142019\"/>

In March 2017, First Lady Melania Trump moved her over to the East Wing.<ref name=\"Fortune06142019\"/><ref name=sentinel_20170327 /> A former White House colleague said that the president regretted losing Grisham to the first lady's office because of Grisham's loyalty and skill at handling the press while acting as his traveling press secretary. During that time, she built relationships with many reporters at events. Despite losing Grisham as part of his own staff, President Trump said he was satisfied that the first lady would \"be in good hands\". Grisham was described by several sources who had worked with her previously as being \"highly competent\" and \"self-aware\"; some suggested that she enjoyed \"trolling the press.\" <ref name=\"Beast\">{{cite web
column3: title=The White House Won't Stop Melania From Contradicting Trump

column1: The [[United States Office of Special Counsel]] stated that Grisham violated the [[Hatch Act of 1939]] following a complaint by Senator [[Tom Carper]]. Grisham was accused of using her official [[Twitter]] account on July 11, 2018, to tweet out Trump's campaign slogan. Violation of the act is not a crime, but a workplace guideline, and the agency responded by sending Grisham a warning letter.<ref name=\"Hatch\">{{cite news
column3: title=Melania Trump's Spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham Violated Hatch Act With 'Make America Great Again' Tweet

column1: In July 2019, Grisham replaced [[Sarah Sanders]] as [[White House Press Secretary
column2: White House press secretary]] and [[White House Communications Director
column5: title=Longtime Trump aide Stephanie Grisham will succeed Sanders as press secretary
column10: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> Grisham's appointment was announced by Melania Trump via [[Twitter]] on June 25, 2019.<ref name=\"Fortune06142019\" /><ref name=cnn_20190625>{{cite news
column12: title=Trump taps Melania Trump's spokeswoman as next White House press secretary
column17: accessdate=September 17, 2019}}</ref> The June 28, 2019 ''Annual Report to Congress on White House Office Personnel'' listed Grisham as \"Assistant to the President and Deputy Chief of Staff for Communications for the First Lady\", with an annual salary of $183,000.00.<ref name=ReportWHpersonnel_20190629>{{cite web
column18: title=Annual Report to Congress on White House Personnel

column1: On September 5, 2019, the ''[[Washington Examiner]]'' published an opinion piece written by Grisham and her deputy [[Hogan Gidley]] entitled, \"The ''Washington Post''{{'}}s lost summer.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column10: accessdate=September 6, 2019}}</ref> The authors asserted the ''Post'' had not reported on several Trump accomplishments that the paper actually did report. In one instance, the piece linked to a ''Post'' story entitled \"Trump becomes first sitting president to set foot into North Korea\" as the authors asserted the paper had not reported the event.<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=Stephanie Grisham Claims ''Washington Post'' Didn't Cover Stories the Paper Actually Did Cover

column1: On September 23, 2019, when asked by the hosts of Fox & Friends if the White House planned to resume its daily press briefing Grisham said \"not right now... I mean, ultimately, if the president decides that it's something we should do, we can do that, but right now he's doing just fine. And to be honest, the briefings have become a lot of theater. And I think that a lot of reporters were doing it to get famous. I mean, yeah, they're writing books now. I mean, they're all getting famous off of this presidency. And so, I think it's great what we're doing now.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House press secretary says daily briefings aren't coming back any time soon

column1: On October 24, 2019, appearing on Fox & Friends, Grisham defended Trump's description of \"Never Trump Republicans\" as \"Human scum\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Never Trumper Republicans, though on respirators with not many left, are in certain ways worse and more dangerous for our Country than the Do Nothing Democrats. Watch out for them, they are human scum!
column9: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref>  When asked if Trump should apologize, Grisham said \"No, no, he shouldn't. The people who are against him and who have been against him and working against his [agenda] since the day they took office are just that. It is horrible that people are working against a president who is delivering results for this country and has been since day one. And, the fact that people continue to try to negate anything he's been trying to do and take away from the good work he's doing on behalf of the American people, they deserve strong language like that.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Press secretary Grisham on Trump's 'human scum' tweet: Those working against him are 'just that'

column1: On October 26, 2019, in response to criticism of President Trump by his former chief of staff Gen. [[John F. Kelly]] (Ret.) Grisham stated: \"I worked with John Kelly, and he was totally unequipped to handle the genius of our President.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House hits back at John Kelly over impeachment remarks

column1: On November 13, 2019, during the testimony of [[William B. Taylor Jr.]], Grisham commented that the [[impeachment inquiry against Donald Trump]] was a \"sham hearing\" that is \"not only boring, it is a colossal waste of taxpayer time & money.\"<ref name=RollCall_20191113>{{cite news
column3: title=White House says Trump 'too busy' to watch 'boring' impeachment hearing
column10: title=Full Video and Analysis of Day 1 of Impeachment Hearing Testimony

column1: That same month, Grisham claimed that Obama administration officials had left \"you will fail\" notes for the incoming Trump administration officials. Numerous Obama administration officials rejected the claim. Grisham ultimately retracted her assertion.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Trump press secretary backtracks claim Obama officials left 'You will fail' notes

column1: In December 2019, Grisham defended President Trump's implication that former congressman [[John Dingell]] was in hell. She described Trump as a \"counter-puncher\" who was \"under attack.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House defends Trump as 'counter-puncher' after he suggests late Michigan congressman in hell
column8: title=White House defends Trump's attack on dead lawmaker John Dingell

column1: On April 7, 2020, it was announced that Grisham left her role as White House Press Secretary and returned to the East Wing to serve as Melania Trump's chief of staff,<ref name=\"CNN-Out\" /> effective that same day.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Grisham leaves role as White House press secretary

column1: As of March 11, 2020, Grisham had not conducted a formal press briefing in 365 days.<ref name=cnn_20200311>{{cite news
column3: title=Make sure to remember this appalling 1-year anniversary
column11: title=Stephanie Grisham: Trump's Press Secretary Who Doesn't Meet the Press
column18: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> However, she appeared on Fox News, Fox Business Network, [[One America News Network]], and the Sinclair Broadcast Group many times during the same period.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /><ref>{{cite news
column20: title=White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham has yet to hold a briefing with reporters, but finds time for Fox News
column25: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' devoted two prime-time segments in one week to question whether taxpayers should pay her $183,000 salary,<ref name=nyt_20200110 /> and her hypocrisy.<ref name=cnn_20200110>{{cite news
column27: title=Cooper to WH press sec.: Your secret is safe with us
column33: access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref> \"Miss Grisham has gone from 'we are human beings' to 'they are human scum.' ... It's actually really kind of sad....\"<ref name=cnn_20200107>{{cite news
column35: title=Cooper calls out White House over lack of press briefings
column43: title=Anderson Cooper Nails Hypocrisy Of Trump Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham
column50: title=Anderson Cooper doubled down in his feud with White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham, calling her statements 'kind of sad'
column55: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> Her \"unintentionally ironic and deeply hypocritical\" social media statements and infrequent televised interviews \"appear meant to defend the president but actually point out the president's own failings.\"<ref name=cnn_20200110 /><ref>{{cite web
column57: title=Anderson Cooper Has A Theory About Stephanie Grisham Secretly Working Against Trump
column62: access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref>  Margaret Sullivan has commented in the ''[[Washington Post]]'' that Grisham \"may hold the title but she's not doing the job\".<ref name=wapo_20200111>{{cite newspaper
column64: title=Stephanie Grisham is not the worst-ever White House press secretary. Here's why.

column1: Authors [[Don Winslow]] and [[Stephen King]] pledged to donate $100,000 each to charity after Grisham held a 60-minute briefing answering questions from the White House press corps.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /> Also, 13 former White House and military press secretaries from three administrations before Trump published a letter calling for the restoration of press briefings.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /><ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Why America needs to hear from its government
column6: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> The press briefings never occurred.<ref>{{Cite news
column10: title=Stephanie Grisham out as White House press secretary after eight months during which she held no regular news briefings
column16: first2=closeAnne GearanWhite House reporterEmailEmailBioBioFollowFollowJosh Dawsey closeJosh DawseyReporter covering the White

column1: On January 9, 2013, Grisham was pulled over for speeding in [[Gilbert, Arizona
column2: Gilbert]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]]. The officer observed Grisham's signs of intoxication, and she failed a field sobriety test. Grisham denied consuming any alcohol, but said she had taken a [[Xanax]] 90 minutes earlier and a [[Zoloft]] the prior night. A blood test revealed Grisham's blood alcohol content to be .105 percent, which is above the .08 legal limit in Arizona. She also was found to be driving on a suspended license since August 2012 for failure to answer a traffic citation. In August 2014, Grisham accepted a plea bargain agreement that reduced the charge to misdemeanor reckless driving, plus two years of probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Like So Many Of His Associates, Donald Trump's New Press Secretary Has Posed For Some Mug Shots
column8: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> She returned to court twice for failure to pay the $779 in fines and failure to complete a [[Mothers Against Drunk Driving]] program.<ref name=azr_20190626 />

column1: Shortly after midnight, December 5, 2015, Grisham was arrested again in [[Phoenix, Arizona
column2: Phoenix]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]] for driving without her headlights and suspicion of [[driving under the influence]]; thus violating her probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> Grisham failed to appear at her court hearing on January 19, 2016,<ref name=azr_20190626 /> whereupon the judge issued a warrant for her arrest.<ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" /> Afterwards, Grisham pleaded guilty.  In July 2016, she was ordered into a treatment program and to pay nearly $1,600 in court costs and fines.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" />

In one instance, the piece linked to a ''Post'' story entitled \"Trump becomes first sitting president to set foot into North Korea\" as the authors asserted the paper had not reported the event.<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=Stephanie Grisham Claims ''Washington Post'' Didn't Cover Stories the Paper Actually Did Cover

column1: On September 23, 2019, when asked by the hosts of Fox & Friends if the White House planned to resume its daily press briefing Grisham said \"not right now... I mean, ultimately, if the president decides that it's something we should do, we can do that, but right now he's doing just fine. And to be honest, the briefings have become a lot of theater. And I think that a lot of reporters were doing it to get famous. I mean, yeah, they're writing books now. I mean, they're all getting famous off of this presidency. And so, I think it's great what we're doing now.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House press secretary says daily briefings aren't coming back any time soon

column1: On October 24, 2019, appearing on Fox & Friends, Grisham defended Trump's description of \"Never Trump Republicans\" as \"Human scum\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Never Trumper Republicans, though on respirators with not many left, are in certain ways worse and more dangerous for our Country than the Do Nothing Democrats. Watch out for them, they are human scum!
column9: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref>  When asked if Trump should apologize, Grisham said \"No, no, he shouldn't. The people who are against him and who have been against him and working against his [agenda] since the day they took office are just that. It is horrible that people are working against a president who is delivering results for this country and has been since day one. And, the fact that people continue to try to negate anything he's been trying to do and take away from the good work he's doing on behalf of the American people, they deserve strong language like that.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Press secretary Grisham on Trump's 'human scum' tweet: Those working against him are 'just that'

column1: On October 26, 2019, in response to criticism of President Trump by his former chief of staff Gen. [[John F. Kelly]] (Ret.) Grisham stated: \"I worked with John Kelly, and he was totally unequipped to handle the genius of our President.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House hits back at John Kelly over impeachment remarks

column1: On November 13, 2019, during the testimony of [[William B. Taylor Jr.]], Grisham commented that the [[impeachment inquiry against Donald Trump]] was a \"sham hearing\" that is \"not only boring, it is a colossal waste of taxpayer time & money.\"<ref name=RollCall_20191113>{{cite news
column3: title=White House says Trump 'too busy' to watch 'boring' impeachment hearing
column10: title=Full Video and Analysis of Day 1 of Impeachment Hearing Testimony

column1: That same month, Grisham claimed that Obama administration officials had left \"you will fail\" notes for the incoming Trump administration officials. Numerous Obama administration officials rejected the claim. Grisham ultimately retracted her assertion.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Trump press secretary backtracks claim Obama officials left 'You will fail' notes

column1: In December 2019, Grisham defended President Trump's implication that former congressman [[John Dingell]] was in hell. She described Trump as a \"counter-puncher\" who was \"under attack.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House defends Trump as 'counter-puncher' after he suggests late Michigan congressman in hell
column8: title=White House defends Trump's attack on dead lawmaker John Dingell

column1: On April 7, 2020, it was announced that Grisham left her role as White House Press Secretary and returned to the East Wing to serve as Melania Trump's chief of staff,<ref name=\"CNN-Out\" /> effective that same day.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Grisham leaves role as White House press secretary

column1: As of March 11, 2020, Grisham had not conducted a formal press briefing in 365 days.<ref name=cnn_20200311>{{cite news
column3: title=Make sure to remember this appalling 1-year anniversary
column11: title=Stephanie Grisham: Trump's Press Secretary Who Doesn't Meet the Press
column18: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> However, she appeared on Fox News, Fox Business Network, [[One America News Network]], and the Sinclair Broadcast Group many times during the same period.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /><ref>{{cite news
column20: title=White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham has yet to hold a briefing with reporters, but finds time for Fox News
column25: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' devoted two prime-time segments in one week to question whether taxpayers should pay her $183,000 salary,<ref name=nyt_20200110 /> and her hypocrisy.<ref name=cnn_20200110>{{cite news
column27: title=Cooper to WH press sec.: Your secret is safe with us
column33: access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref> \"Miss Grisham has gone from 'we are human beings' to 'they are human scum.' ... It's actually really kind of sad....\"<ref name=cnn_20200107>{{cite news
column35: title=Cooper calls out White House over lack of press briefings
column43: title=Anderson Cooper Nails Hypocrisy Of Trump Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham
column50: title=Anderson Cooper doubled down in his feud with White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham, calling her statements 'kind of sad'
column55: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> Her \"unintentionally ironic and deeply hypocritical\" social media statements and infrequent televised interviews \"appear meant to defend the president but actually point out the president's own failings.\"<ref name=cnn_20200110 /><ref>{{cite web
column57: title=Anderson Cooper Has A Theory About Stephanie Grisham Secretly Working Against Trump
column62: access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref>  Margaret Sullivan has commented in the ''[[Washington Post]]'' that Grisham \"may hold the title but she's not doing the job\".<ref name=wapo_20200111>{{cite newspaper
column64: title=Stephanie Grisham is not the worst-ever White House press secretary. Here's why.

column1: Authors [[Don Winslow]] and [[Stephen King]] pledged to donate $100,000 each to charity after Grisham held a 60-minute briefing answering questions from the White House press corps.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /> Also, 13 former White House and military press secretaries from three administrations before Trump published a letter calling for the restoration of press briefings.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /><ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Why America needs to hear from its government
column6: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> The press briefings never occurred.<ref>{{Cite news
column10: title=Stephanie Grisham out as White House press secretary after eight months during which she held no regular news briefings
column16: first2=closeAnne GearanWhite House reporterEmailEmailBioBioFollowFollowJosh Dawsey closeJosh DawseyReporter covering the White

column1: On January 9, 2013, Grisham was pulled over for speeding in [[Gilbert, Arizona
column2: Gilbert]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]]. The officer observed Grisham's signs of intoxication, and she failed a field sobriety test. Grisham denied consuming any alcohol, but said she had taken a Xanax 90 minutes earlier and a Zoloft the prior night. A blood test revealed Grisham's blood alcohol content to be .105 percent, which is above the .08 legal limit in Arizona. She also was found to be driving on a suspended license since August 2012 for failure to answer a traffic citation. In August 2014, Grisham accepted a plea bargain agreement that reduced the charge to misdemeanor reckless driving, plus two years of probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Like So Many Of His Associates, Donald Trump's New Press Secretary Has Posed For Some Mug Shots
column8: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> She returned to court twice for failure to pay the $779 in fines and failure to complete a [[Mothers Against Drunk Driving]] program.<ref name=azr_20190626 />

column1: Shortly after midnight, December 5, 2015, Grisham was arrested again in [[Phoenix, Arizona
column2: Phoenix]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]], for driving without her headlights and suspicion of [[driving under the influence]]; thus violating her probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> Grisham failed to appear at her court hearing on January 19, 2016,<ref name=azr_20190626 /> whereupon the judge issued a warrant for her arrest.<ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" /> Afterwards, Grisham pleaded guilty.  In July 2016, she was ordered into a treatment program and to pay nearly $1,600 in court costs and fines.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" />

column1: * [https://azcapitoltimes.com/news/tag/stephanie-grisham/ Stephanie Grisham] at the ''[[Arizona Capitol Times]]''
